reviews.review: Fantastic!. We really enjoyed our time at the planetarium. It's a family operated place and they're all really lovely people. We learned so much about the Incan night sky and got to see Saturn and the moon through telescopes which I'll never forget! Really inexpensive and a must do if you're at all interested in the stars/planets/etc.

Fantastic evening in Cuzco. Family operated planetarium, it included a view of the sky as well as some history about astronomy done by the Incas. It is a lovely family, you shouldn't skip this one at all!

Great way to spend the evening. A visit to this family-operated attraction is a great way to spend the evening in Cusco. The cost is 50 soles, which includes a ride to and from central Cusco, and the program is offered in English. You need to make reservations using their website, but you don't actually pay until the end of the program that evening.The planetarium show was excellent and provides a basic overview of astronomy, the night sky over Cusco, and its importance to the Incas. However, the highlight was the telescope viewing. We looked at Saturn (which was spectacular!), the moon, Mars, two star clusters, and a binary star system. Make sure to check the weather forecast before you go because overcast or rainy weather will obviously impact the telescope viewing.

Wonderful. This is a a family run planetarium. Everyone there is so passionate about the culture and stars. I learned a lot about the Inca culture and how they used astronomy. The staff do a great job pointing out the different constellations. We got to look through the telescopes and see stars and planets. It is chilly they did provide a blanket. Highly recommend!

Feel their passion!. Not too many people know about this place in Cuzco, I am glad I found it on Tripadvisor. You start with a very interesting explanation about how the quechua people used astronomy in their lives, you also see the constellations at the domo and what is the best part is to go out to see the sky through their telescopes. I went there twice, the first night was a little bit cloudy but we could see Saturn, some constellations and the Milky Way; the sky was much better the second evening and I had the honor of sharing some more time with Mr. Erwin Salazar while the rest of the group received the introduction, so he showed me different celestial bodies and it was great to know more about how the Planetarium started, then I laid down on the grass to watch the stars while the rest of the group were looking through the telescopes! IT WAS AMAZING, clear skies in a magic place! Just bring a very good jacket because nights in Cusco are cold.

Wonderful experience. This family-run planetarium was a delight. The love of their culture and the stars is evident. I learned a lot about the Incas and the stars. Best of all was looking through their many telescopes. Priceless!

A higlight of my Cusco trip. Well worth the money. I wanted to get acquainted with the southern sky before heading off for my Salkantay trek. It turns out this was the only time I saw any stars - the moon was either too bright or the clouds too thick - so I am double grateful I got a chance to visit the planetarium. Next time I am south of the equator I will come during a new moon!

Fun but pricey . This was a really nice excursion - pick up was prompt, the guide was enthusiastic and knowledgable, and the setting was comfortable. However, I would say it's only worth it if the sky is clear. 50 soles is a lot to pay for just the presentation itself so make sure to check the weather forecast beforehand!!

Fun, Random Experience. The planetarium in Cusco was really cool - neat to hear about the stars from the Inka perspective. Their culture was very advanced in terms of astronomy, and relied heavily on the stars to master agriculture as well. Tour picked us up in Cusco, and once we arrived, they gave us a bit of a lesson, let us see stars and constellations ourselves through their giant telescopes, and then showed us the classic dark room planetarium stars. Note, it was one of our first nights in Cusco and we hadn't realized how cold it can get once the sun sets. Take a jacket! You will be outside for part of it.

Family business that cares. I really enjoyed the planetarium in Cusco (it's actually just outside Cusco's valley). The family that owns and operates it is very excited about cosmology, and this rubs off in their presentations. They are so clearly excited about their planet, the stars, and the cosmos. That enthusiasm makes the visit worth it.

Freezing but fun!. They aren't joking when they say to wear lots of layers--but they hand out blankets as well, which is very nice. You're picked up in a square near the Plaza de Armas and driven up near Sacsayhuaman. There's a little intro and then some star gazing and a planetarium show. Unfortunately it was a full moon, so we weren't able to see a lot of stars with the naked eye, but they still looked gorgeous in the telescopes! Overall a fun experience!

Great information on Inca understanding of the cosmos. This is a family run business which offers interesting insights into the southern night sky. The tour picks up from one of the smaller plazas in central Cusco and takes people in a bus to the planetarium, which is a small building next to a playing field away from the bright lights of Cusco. Stars and planets are viewed from telescopes on the lawn, and the planetarium is in fact a projection onto the ceiling of the building. Nevertheless it is very interesting particularly when discussing Inca understanding of the stars, and those from the northern hemisphere get an explanation of the southern night sky and a look at the milky way if the night is clear. Dress warmly and choose a night with no moon, for best viewing

Interesting and educational experience!. Our experience in Planetarium Cusco was great! We were picked up in downtown Cusco in the early evening. A mini bus takes you to the Planetarium. We were presented information on the significance of astrology for the Incas, which I found incredibly interesting. In a special room simulating the night sky, we then learned more about different constellations and how to recognise them. In the end, we observed the night sky through telescopes. I enjoyed the fact that the Planetarium is a family business. Everyone was also very passionate about what they were doing.Really worth a visit!

Fabulous & interesting experience!. We decided to give this a try as something a bit different and we were not disappointed! You meet in the square and are taken to the planetarium near the Sascy ruins. Our guide was great with good English and a good knowledge of astronomy, it mainly focused on the Southern Hemisphere and he gave a good explanation of how the Inca's etc used the night sky to guide them. Following a history on the Inca's we went into the planetarium dome where we learnt more about how the Southern and Northern Hemispheres worked and about the constellations which was fab. The final part of the tour was outside looking at the stars both with the naked eye and through the telescope. This part was done by a different guide who clearly knew a lot about the stars and planets and was very passionate. He used a laser to point out the constellations then we used the telescope to view star clusters, Mars, Saturn and most impressively of all the moon. Def worth the 50 soles each to experience this!

Highlight of my trip to Peru. I'm an amateur astronomer and whenever traveling I carry my portable telescope to both observe objects I don't get to see in my location in the US as well as share with others the splendors of the sky.My wife discovered the existence of this planetarium and we booked a visit the only night we were free. We were met at a park in downtown Cusco and driven to the Planetarium's location out of town.We were absolutely amazed at this family run passion project. Upon arriving we were brought into a room and given a brief introduction on how the different Inca sites are aligned with the Winter and Summer Solstices. For such a small operation they had huge backlit photographs professionally made and hung on the wall.After this intro we went inside their planetarium, a room they had installed a spherical ceiling into, and their own homemade star and constellation projectors. For such a small operation the way they created this planetarium was absolutely ingenious. Here we were given a tour of the Southern Hemisphere stars. Following this was a very professional slide show that explained the Incan constellations. Even though I'm an avid astronomer I learned a great deal from this part of the tour.Finally, the tour ends outside looking at objects in the sky through two telescopes and a pair of binoculars they have on hand. At this point the tour was handed over to the Uncle who excitedly showed us Mars, Saturn, and the double star Albireo. Unfortunately, the night was hazy so we couldn't observe any deep sky objects.If you are visiting Cusco definitely keep an eye on the weather and book a trip to the planetarium! As I said before, it's a family run passion project that was informative even for experienced astronomers, great for kids, and filled with enthusiasm for the subject. My wife and I are already making plans to return in a year and want to visit this place again.

Enthusiastic family-run operation. Pick-up from central Cusco, they take you out to their building and give a short lecture explaining importance of sky to Incas, then take you into their Planetarium dome. Then they take you outside and point out different constellations and planets through their 2 telescopes. This latter part is cold (it's late, dark). Wear really warm clothes!

A great evening of learning - for adults and kids. We had so much fun at the planetarium. The family that runs it is so knowledgeable and so passionate that it is infectious. We learned about the stars in the southern hemisphere and about Incan astronomy, then went out and used their telescopes to see some incredible sights. Our kids loved it, but we did too - and most of the people there were adults
Inca Sky. Very informative, educational view of the constellations the Inca saw. One of our favorite activities in Cusco. Dress warmly.

A definite highlight! . We booked to do the planetarium due to the excellent reviews and my love of space and what an amazing choice. We were picked up from the centre of Cusco and driven out to the family run planetarium high up in the mountains. Such a beautiful tranquil place. The family were so informative and passionate about space. Outside we saw clearly Jupiter, Mars and Saturn it was simply stunning. This was definitely one of our favourite trips and would highly recommend a visit.
Educational. Extremely interesting and educational. The best part was the woman who guided us through. She had a great personality and made everything interesting and entertaining.

Interesting trip!!. We booked this on a whim and were able to get in same day! It was a quick trip but definitely worth it. You will hear a lot about Incan history- but the best part is when they take you in their planetarium and project the stars/constellations. The stories and information we heard here about the Incan relationship with the stars and sky were very unique. this isn't something you can hear about on a city tour or anything. And it was a really cool way to get ready for our trek to Machu Picchu- we were able to recognize constellations where we were hiking! Only downside was that it was a cloudy night so we weren't able to see anything out of their telescopes.

Unique Experience! Group was way too big!. We were really looking forward to this very unique experience – and it was truly something very special! The evening was very informative and after an interesting talk, we went outside and got to look through three different very powerful telescopes, aimed at the moon, the nearest star to earth visible from the Southern hemisphere and a planet with it’s moons. We were in awe at what we saw! It was absolutely freezing, despite our thermals and layers of clothing, gloves and hats! Our hosts handed out blankets to everyone, which really made a huge difference, especially while we were outside. We booked a private experience by email directly with our hosts and shortly before our departure to Peru, the date was changed due to a personal commitment on their end, which understandably happens, but we would no longer have a private experience, which was quite disappointing. Our hosts met us in Cusco at the agreed meeting point in Cusco to drive us up to their home. (No charge for the ride!) Our hosts were absolutely lovely, very personable and likeable – quite funny and quirky too. The talk we had was very interesting and we really enjoyed it. We especially enjoyed the comparison between modern astrology and the way the Inkas and ancient people of Peru viewed and utilised the stars. The only criticism I can offer is to limit the group sizes. We were about 40 people and it was a tight fit. We had to be split into two groups, which caused a bit of a disorganized situation a few times. Also, with the viewing through the telescopes we had to line up for quite some time and then got only a few seconds to have a quick look. If the group was much smaller it would have been more manageable and a more unique and personal experience - and everyone would have had enough time at the telescopes. Getting back to Cusco could not be done all in one go and we had to wait for the first round of buses to return before we finally got our turn. It was absolutely freezing and a very uncomfortable wait. Take a torch for the walk back to the minibus – it is pitch black and there are stairs involved! Lucky we had ours! I would certainly recommend this experience, but fork out the extra money and do a private tour (then hope it won’t be cancelled).

Fascinating family business, not just for star gazers. Had this recommended and would recommend to others. You are taken by bus out of town and then three stage visit with first part on Incas and the stars, then planetarium type show and finally out side to look through telescopes. I am not a star gazer but was fascinated as were both teenage kids. But wrap up warm, blankets were provided but it's cold. Family business, privately run and their enthusiasm came through.

Planetarium Cusco. I went here with my tour group. A pleasant evening out. A small planetarium but extremely informative. We were provided with blankets to keep us warm and whilst inside the heater was also on. Time was spent inside with a ceiling screen presentation then outside to view through the telescope.

A different Cusco experience!. A wonderful family run experience! You will be picked up with the rest of the evening's group close to plaza de armas and taken up above Cusco to a nice house/garden in a minivan. The rest of the evening will be spent in a small planetarium learning about new, old and Inka specific zodiacs , learning about the stars importance to the Inkas and gazing at Saturn's rings through telescopes. Bring warm clothes for the last part, but no worries if you forget - there are lots of blankets. We loved it, thank you!

Impressive and worthwhile.. I was travelling with some Canadian students (14-18 yrs old) during spring break and we booked a tour at the planetarium as we had some free time while in Cusco. I admit I wasn't expecting much but I was totally impressed after our tour. I'm amazed at the love, dedication and commitment the family has to share and teach others about astronomy. Loved looking through the telescopes to see Jupiter, the moon and a cluster of stars, breathtaking!! We ALL had an enjoyable evening and definitely one of the highlights of my trip to Peru :)
Interesting visit. I'm from the northern hemisphere so this was interesting. First time I have seen the southern cross. The guide was very enthusiastic about the planetarium.

Tied everything together. The tour was interesting and helped tie together all the information we had learned at other sites. The stars were very important to the Inca empire. The guide spoke good English and was funny.

Loved This!. We recently spent four days in Cusco before we started our journey on the 4-day Classic Inca Trail hike. On our second night, we visited the family-run planetarium and we couldn't be more pleased with our decision! Not only did we learn about the constellations of the Incas, but also more of their history. It was really helpful as we visited the Sacred Valley the next day - especially Ollantaytambo! I would definitely recommend this to anyone planning to spend time in Cusco, and I'd suggest doing it early in your visit. It's was a great experience, taught us a lot and allowed us to impress the other hikers with our knowledge of the stars once we got on the trail!

Great way to learn about the sky you'll see on trail!. Just 2 hour experience but you learn a lot about the southern sky. I saw Jupiter and Saturn for the first time with their huge telescopes. They pick up and drop you off and offer both Spanish and English presentations. I'm excited to have gone this before my Salkantay hike where I'll get an amazing view of the Milky Way!!

Inka Skys. This is a small family run planetarium with an amazing view of the night sky. It's on a historical reserve of sorts so the facility is built in a very Cusco fashion. If you speak or understand Spanish I recommend you take the tour in Spanish (of course the English tour is great also) The head of organization is an astrology professor with an amazing way of being informative and entertaining in a story telling sort of way. It's definitely worth it! Oh and if you are going in Peruvian winter dress warmly!

Great! . We had a wonderful time - our guide Jose was very passionate and knowledgable about astronomy and related it to inca history. They have their own made projector which was informative and visually spectacular. Furthermore, we got to see Mars, Jupiter and Saturn! I have to say a special thanks because I wasn't feeling well - the staff were so lovely and facilitated me seeing Mars, Jupiter and Saturn after the rest of the group - thank you! Well worth a visit!

Fantastic Experience!. We had a great time on the tour. The company is family run and all of them are passionate and extremely knowledgeable about the subject. I learned so much on my tour. It was definitely a highlight of my time in Cusco!

Gorgeous evening. Had the best time here, if you have the time in Cusco you should absolutely check it out. It's a family run operation and they absolutely love what they do. It is utterly magical standing outside stargazing with other travellers, a really special evening.
If you are in Cuzco, do this. . Amazing evening. The hosts know their stuff, it's part Inka history, part stars. Brilliant way to spend the evening.

Lots of fun!. First, to fully appreciate how much fun we had a little background is needed. We did this on our first day in Cusco. We were all feeling terrible. The altitude was taking its toll on us. And it was really cold. There was debate about even going since we were hurting, but we did go. And we had a blast! The hosts are extremely passionate about space and the stars so you can't help but get excited too. Two of our family of three are space nerds, so getting to see Jupiter through the telescope was really exciting.

Enjoyable but not spectacular. This family run planaterium sits on the hills above Cusco. The night we went it was overcast so the only star gazing was inside at the roof. The show was interesting but not brilliant. They showed the different constellations visible in the Southern Hemisphere. The bench around the wall was uncomfortable after a while. We were given a blanket to put around us.They weren't pushy to up sell any souvenirs.

Incredible night of stargazing! . I went to the Planetarium my first night in Cusco. Privately run by a local family, they pick you up between 5:45 and 6pm from downtown Cuzco and take you to the Planetarium site, up narrow, rocky roads and your very own adventure. I felt safe with our guides, and they clearly have it down to a science because at least two other groups were there that same night. You start indoors, where they explain the stars and how to spot them. If you're usd to the Northern Hemisphere, it's a treat to see the Big Dipper upside down! They have blankets available towards the back, make sure to grab some! It gets cold outside. Once outside, they'll point out various stars and planets that you can see either with the naked eye or through the telescope. On my night, we saw Jupiter! Really cool, not rushed so you have time to enjoy or look again if you want. Could use some snack or hot beverage option. You pay in soles before you leave, 50 per person.Wonderful nighttime activity! Definitely go!

I expected more. First of all - it's a PRIVATE planetarium. I was hoping to experience something unique but experience was average. They picked us up in Cusco and drove 5 minutes up the hill. I thought we will go into the wild so we could enjoy the best conditions to watch stars. But the place is still within the city, so you get all this glare from city lights ! First part was interesting - when they talked about stars and legends. But part in which we actually watch the stars is really so-so. They have one mid size telescope, so you won't see a lot of details... I must say it was way overpriced experience.It's a family business so I wish them all the best, but there is a lot of things they can improve:-move your base further away (to total darkness) and give more time for individual experience- make smaller groups - it's not good to wait for your turn for telescope in a group of 20 people- lower your price or offer better experience

not the number one of the activity you can do in Cusco. The introduction was OK, I had a few new informations. looking the stars.. mmm.. I expected to see more than this with telescopes! was for me not very special.. the planetarium at the end was OK.our guide was friendly and it's good organised. I think is not the number one of the activity you can do in Cusco.. but if you have a lot of time.. then do it. it's not expensive.

An excellent educational and entertaining evening. We were taken by mini-buses from the square up to the observatory on the hillside above Cusco about 10 minutes drive away.The evening was split into three: general details of the sky at night and the constellations, information about the Inca astronomy and finally practical viewings through binoculars and a telescope.The evening's group was split into three with each sub-group rotating through the activities. It was very well organised and wonderful to see the enthusiasm of the family members as they took us through their presentations.A really excellent and informative evening and highly recommended, but wrap up warm as it can get cold up on the hill at night!

Perfect evening activity. We were able to get into to this activity through our hotel. It was well worth the 50 Sol per person. They show you Inca constellations and their meanings and let you star gaze outside as well. We had a great view of Jupiter. Bring warm clothes because it gets chilly at night. Also their dog gandalf is great.
A most interesting night. We were a group of 7 and we all enjoyed our experience learning about the Inca sky and seeing it with our gracious hosts. Do not miss this one!!

A must-see if you're in Cusco! . This is my first Trip Advisor review, but I feel so strongly that I have to write about the planetarium. They were able to squeeze is in last minute, and everything was very well run and organized. We started in the planetarium and learned about constellations in the northern and southern skies. Everyone in this family-run business is extremely knowledgeable. We then learned about Inca constellations, ancient time telling, and how they learned to predict the weather. Finally, we went outside to stargaze. We saw a few clusters that you are not able to see with the naked eye, as well as Mars, Jupiter and 3 of its moons. Bring a warm coat for this part. They also provide blankets if you need them. It is the perfect amount of time, and they drop you back in Cusco just in time for dinner!

Great experience!. It was a great experience and we learned a lot! Would definitely recommend as a way to spend an evening in cusco! You meet in a square in cusco and travel by van to the planetarium nearby. The guides were very friendly and knowledgeable.

Very educational and fun visit. Very knowledgeable and passionate guide. Great overview and introduction to the Southern sky and the ancient Incas’ constellations. Made us want to stay up all night to learn and see more. Saw Jupiter's bands and its four Galilean moons.

Excellent. Visited May 2016 and thoroughly enjoyed myself. The telescopes showed us Jupiter and its moons as well as earths moon and some stars. Planetarium itself was good but the stars of the show are the family that run this place. Very funny and informative and made the experience all the more enjoyable! Recommended!

Family Run and Wonderful. They pick you up in the center of Cusco and drive you up to the planetarium on the hill. This was a great introduction to the night sky of the southern hemisphere and some of the cosmology of the Incas. If you are lucky enough to get a clear night, they will bring out some telescopes so you can view some planets and stars (whatever is visible that night).This was a perfect activity before trekking as we were then able to identify some constellations from our campsites in the mountains.
Really interesting!. A very interesting and informative guide to the constellations. Very highly recommend it for people visiting Cusco.
Star gazing. Fantastic planetarium. Guide was so enthusiastic, you couldn't help but love it. Saw stars and constellations. Great evening.

Interesting astronomy event!. Get to know the southern sky.
Listen to interesting stories about Inca astronomy.
Good way to spend time after sunset in Cuzco.
Would be even better if observe more objects.

Interesting. The people that run this private planetarium are certainly enthusiastic. It is really an audio visual show with some interesting Constellations drawings on a dome ceiling. Not a full scale Planetarium by any means. They have two telescopes outside and it can be cool so dress warm. This affords you a closer look at a particular constellation or even a planet. We saw Jupiter. A long drive from Cusco however and on an iffy road.

Very informative. We went here because my girlfriend loves the stars, I had no clue about astronomy but learned a great deal about it on this tour. all the explanations were great and we had a clear night, so we could check all what we learnt on the sky

Excellent visit. I'm not a astronomy enthusiast but I enjoyed every minute of this visit. This is not a high tech planetarium but a family business, which made this different and fun. The staff (family) were very professional and passionate about their jobs, making this visit very memorable. Definitely worth a visit and experience something different other than the Inca ruins.

Very enjoyable evening . Our visit to this small family run planetarium was a great way to spend an evening. The love and excitement the staff feel for astronomy and Incan/Quechua culture is very contagious. Highly recommend to anyone who likes the night sky.

Really cool and different. A really neat family run star program. They pick you up in buses from the city center and take you up the windy road to their homemade planetarium dome just outside the city really close to saskeewama. Jose the English guide gave a really nice heartfelt introduction to Incan astronomy. This was followed by an insightful planetarium dome presentation, and lastly a real view of the stars thru telescopes. Despite the family probably doing this show every night, it was such a pleasure to see how they were so into it.

Charming and enjoyable. We visited the planetarium yesterday evening with our children ages 3, 7 and 9. Although it is not exactly geared for kids, the presenters are so engaging and kind and accommodating, that our kids really enjoyed the experience, as did my husband and I. My favorite part was learning about the Inca constellations and connections to the culture. But it is a full planetarium presentation, so you also get a great review of the Greek constellations and astronomical distances, etc..

Better than Cusco tour!!!. I said better than Cusco tours, because the Planetarium's staff really KNOW what they are doing, they take it serious and they really love what they are doing, they are not improvised locals trying to get money from tourist like I experienced with the tourist guides.I am very happy with the experience, specially my children enjoyed it !!100% recommended.

Enthusiastic staff and intimate stargazing experience.. Great evening activity for any age. We had a cloudy night but the enthusiasm of the staff and fellow travellers made the experience very enjoyable. Very knowlegeable and friendly staff. Easy pickup Regocijo Square.

A great little planetarium. My daughters (10 and 12) , my husband and I had a great time. We were unlucky with the weather because it was very cloudy but we managed to see Pluto. Our guide was very passionate about the incas and the sky. Definitely worth a visit
what a amazing night. watching at the faraway stars and constellations make me travel in imagination to the origins of our universew...its a educating visit, recommendable.

Great Experience to enhance the Cusco experience!. I was not sure what to expect but I was pleasantly surprised by the experience. The staff knows what they are talking about, they are entertaining and informative! If you have a couple of hours one evening this is well worth the time and the money!
Amazing stars. Very nice excursion after which I can said that stars come closer to me)) nice lecture and wonderful experience of sky observing)

Educational and fun!. If you have any interest in astrology, you should definitely check out the Planetarium. The people are lovely, know their stuff and fun. We were unable to view the night sky because of rain, but we still learned a ton and were reluctant to leave when our time ended.

Best museum/attraction experience ever!!. What can i say. I was planning this visit as a surprise for my girlfriend on our last night in cusco, and boy was it wort it...the way they explained everything with so much passion and enthusiasm was incredible, i wish all my teachers in high school would have been like that haha. I loved seeing my gf listening with an open mouth, im sure i had a similar expression on.my face...after talking to us about inka astronomy, they took us to their small dome, it was fantastic! I cannot describe everything here, there was too much shown amd talked about, all i will say is go go go!!! If you have the chance to:)Sadly there were alot of clouds there for the last part, star gazing, but nothing else could be expected for that time of the year. Still, that didnt change the fact that we both looooved the tour, and we are coming back in june to see you guys again, and gandalf ;)Lukas & maricielo

Passionate folks and informative presentation. Jose and his family run this humble planetarium. They pick you up at Plaza Regocijo, so keep your eyes peeled while you're waiting so you don't miss the pickup. They provide a very informative presentation on astronomy and how it affected the early cultures of Peru. This is followed by a presentation in the planetarium dome and then gazing at the moon and stars (if visible) through some high-powered telescopes and binoculars. We weren't quite as wowed as we anticipated based on the reviews, but it was still a unique experience and we're happy to support a family that is passionate about educating folks on early astronomy. Although they provide some blankets, I'd recommend bringing a warm jacket as it gets cold once the sun sets.
Planetarium Tour. took this tour with my family, make sure you bring a warm coat as it can get very windy up at the mountain for night observation. Would recommend the tour.

A highlight (excuse the pun) of Cusco. You travel uphill out of Cusco to an isolated site in a small valley. We first had an explanation of the constellations in each hemisphere - it's a long time since I learned so much in such a short time. We then moved through to the dome to look at the skies as we see them and learn how the Incas developed a total connection with their environment. Sadly the skies weren't clear but this didn't detract from our enjoyment. A really knowledgeable and interesting member of the family brought the skies to life. Wrap up warm if you're going in winter.

Absolutely AMAZING! . This is a lovely family run business, and our guide did a fantastic job explaining to us all the stars, constellations, ancient beliefs and its many stories. You also get to learn about how astronomy shaped agriculture back in the Inka period which is absolutely fascinating. The place is built in a lovely serene area where you could easily see stars during the non cloudy season. Unfortunately, the sky was completely clouded on the night of our visit but we were not left disappointed at all because the dome and its projections along with the guide's excellent presentations more than made up for it! I have not met someone who explained the stars so well and with such animation! An absolutely memorable evening. Do come - you won't be disappointed!

Excellent!. We really loved our visit to the small and charming family run Planetarium. Jose was the perfect, super knowledgable host (on astrology but also Inca's in general) and the dome with the projection of the night sky and presentation on Inca astrology all very interesting. A good activity even if it's cloudy because so much of the presentation is done in the dome. one of our favourite Cusco outings.

AMAZING!!!. So worth a evening in Cusco! This is a family owned business and they do an excellent job explaining the role of the stars in Incan history. Then they take you outside with a nice telescope and look at the night sky. We were able to see the moon and Saturn along with her rings.

GO!!!!!!!. This planetarium is modest but is very intimate and the people running it are amazing and so passionate about what they do. I had one of my favorite times in Cusco at the planetarium Cusco! It is barely advertised but worth every sole! I would go 10 times if I could but we are leaving tomorrow. You are also supporting a local, family run, operation. I would give it 6 stars if possible. GO!!

May want to skip in the cloudy season; See Sacsayhuaman on the drive up.. I emailed Ana Maria if there were any last minute open spots for a tour on the same day. Ana Maria was very responsive, and luckily for me, there was a tour that night (they are typically not open on Sundays, but this time they happened to have a large tour participating, so I was able to come along—so if you only have time on a Sunday, you might as well shoot an email to ask).Set your expectations a bit low…this is nothing like the planetarium in large cities (I was a bit worried when we pulled up to a small farm-like area with llamas in the front yard), though they have a dome where they show constellations. The pick up was at 5:40, and the lecture lasted about 1.5 hours. We were supposed to then go outside to spot constellations, but as we were in the rainy season (their summer month of January), and so we couldn’t see anything. I did appreciate that they are a family-run business that operate out of labors of love. They genuinely care about the environment and human connection to it. I hope that they can survive. Also, an added addition: I didn’t have the chance to see Sacsayhuaman. (Well, I decided to skip it, actually, because I figured it wouldn’t have compared to Machu Picchu). The “observatory” is located close to Sacsayhuaman, and so I got to see most of it on the drive up the hill. Student price: 30 soles. Adult price: 50 soles (I’m not sure I would have paid the 50 sole admission fee…).

Worth a visit!. If you are into astronomy and the stars this is a very cool place to visit! The owner and his nephew are very passionate about their work with the sky and have very cool information to share. You have the opportunity to look into 2 different telescopes and see different stars and constellations for yourself! Part of the tour is indoors and part is outdoors. They do offer you blankets to keep warm outside but if you tend to get cold in chilly weather bring an extra layer. Definitely worth a visit!

Interesting, relaxed and informative evening. Visited the family run planetarium before Christmas with the family and it was great - really well presented and very informative - pickup from near the chocolate museum was very handy - recommended for families - dress warm as it gets chilly after the sun goes down.

A great experience in a small family-owned planetarium. This is definitely an experience I would recommend. They have their own private transport from the center of Cusco and the tour has several parts - a presentation about Inca astronomy, a planetarium projection focusing on the Southern constellations, and observations outside if weather permits. Our tour guide was quite knowledgeable and showed us a few important stars and objects in the sky. Many of the facts he told us were very interesting - for example that the Incas knew how to predict El Nino from the brightness level of the Pleiades. As constructive criticism, I would point out that when we went outside to observe it was still twilight, so do it later in the summer months. Also, the observation outside was too short - by the time it got really dark and it happened to clear up a bit, we had to go. I would have liked to have the option to stay longer in their yard in order to observe, maybe even by my own. Perhaps they can give that option and then call you a taxi? The observations outside did not focus much on the Southern Sky, which is why I went primarily - most tourists would be from the Northern hemisphere I imagine. Overall a very worthwhile and recommended experience.

Don't miss this if you're in Cusco!. I don't want to give you any high hopes before your visit but I can't lie to you when I say that this was probably one of the best experiences I had in Cusco. To really appreciate this lovely evening at the Planetarium I'd recommend you to atleast visit the Qurikancha or Machu Picchu.This family business is very passionate and this is felt throughout the whole tour. I was completely mind-blown when I left the place. It felt as if this event was the ribbon that tied up all of the new information I had absorbed about the Inkas deep connection with the nature and cosmos.I was also genuinely happy to see that some of that spirit didn't fade out with time but rather was passed on into this family.I can agree with some of the negative comments that the meeting in the plaza seemed somewhat unorganized, but you have to be somewhat distracted if you do not see the young gentleman in a blue jacket with the planetarium logo on it.We had a bus leaving just before the tour was over, the staff were very kind to us and arranged an earlier transport for us so that we wouldn't miss it.I miss Gandalf already! (for those who make a visit)

my family is crazy for the stars. We could learn more of the universe by watching to the program on this planetarium, and with the help of the owner, possible to watch & identify some constellations, stars and the moon (that night the sky was quite clear)...it was very interesting and educating to sign for this tour.

Very knowledgable host; we learned a lot. We had an evening free in Cusco and made arrangements for this visit. This is a family business. We were met on time at the exact location and escorted to the planetarium. The young man who gave the lecture was very well informed and told us facts that we found useful later as we toured Machu Picchu. Unfortunately, it was cloudy and we did not get to star gaze but it was an enjoyable, informative evening.

Awesome evening!. My two friends and I visited the planetarium during our stay in Cusco. It was such a great evening! You're picked up from a square and taken about 10-15 min outside of the city to a family run farm-esque feeling place. The family that owns the planetarium is clearly passionate about what they do which in turn also made my friends and I excited. There are two parts to the evening...the first part starts inside their planetarium where you learn about southern hemisphere constellations. The second part you go outside and get to look through their telescopes. They provide blankets but definitely suggest bringing jackets and sweaters because it can get very cold at night!

great way to spend an evening in Cusco. This was a well run family operation that offered lots of great information. We did this our first night in Cusco and it was a great way to be out without being overly active while acclimatizing to the altitude. Very interesting to learn about how the Inca used the stars. Worthwhile

Fascinating place. Run by a Family who explain everything so interesting
A must if you have time and visiting Cuzco
you can even look through the telescopes ans see Saturn

Very enjoyable. One of the highlights of our trip to South America. Enthusiastic team gave very engaging presentation following which we were able to look through telescopes at the night sky. We even got to see saturn's rings! Definitely worth a visit.

Good visit, good information and well presented. The visit was great, I would say a bit short and quick. At the end of the session we were supposed to use the telescope, but the guy who does it was not there, and our guide was not experienced with it, although he has good knowledge of what he spoke about

Enthusiastic and interesting! . This little gem is kept very quiet in Cusco but I'm delighted a friend suggested we go! Family run planetarium, uncle picks you up from plaza regocijo at 5.40pm and brings you up to the planetarium where his niece and nephew talk you through the importance of astronomy to the Incas. The dome simulates the southern hemisphere sky where they point out all the important constellations and then take you outside to look through binoculars and telescopes. Impressive work even on the cloudy night we were there! Well worth a trip. Suitable for all ages.

Cloudy night - not much to see. They are really passionate about astronomy and provide lots of information about Inca beliefs in relation to the stars as well as modern theories. Unfortunately it was really cloudy the night that we went which meant once we got outside we couldn't see much at all. However, the indoor stuff was amazing. It gets VERY cold, even indoors, so rug up.
Well worth a couple of hours of your time. Learn about the stars with a very nice host in this family run business. For the sake of 50 Soles per person it's well worth the money

Educational, Fun and Friendly!. My travel partner and I really like astronomy, and had never learned about the Southern skies. We called the planetarium from our hotel, and they left a message for us telling us they were open. They picked us up in a tourist van at a nearby square, a guy in a Planetarium Cusco jacket came to find us. They take you up the mountain aboout 15 minutes to a small family place with a "farm" type feel. The tour takes about 2 hours, and begins with an introduction to Inca history and mythology. We then got to see a star map and interactive presentation, learning about the night skies and galaxies visible at this time of year. It really set the stage for actually looking through the telescope outside! Jose was fantastic, and the blankets we got were a nice touch! I highly recommend this as an early evening activity-- just be sure to bring warm clothes!

Enjoy Maltesers with your eyes! Yummy Yummy Yummy.... Have you tried Maltesers before? Come here to enjoy it with your eyes. If you join the sunset and moon rise tour, you are able to view not only the sunset scenery with Milky Way and sunset ray but the moon rises. The brightness of the moon is irresistance to taste like the inner layer of Maltesers. I have never viewed and to know that the moon is so so bright under the telescope. Do drop by Colca Canyon and enjoy this marvelous experience that I once have had just a couple of weeks ago.

Absolutely wonderful!. We decided it would be worth learning about the constellations so we could understand a little better what we'd be seeing at night on our Machu Picchu trek, and wow, this Planetarium is worth the visit! Ana Maria's enthusiasm is contagious. She was a wonderful teacher, as was her uncle. The Planetarium is a family run business, and their passion for the stars was incredible. Not only did we get to see the constellations projected in their dome, but we also went outside and saw star clusters, the moon and Saturn with its rings, through their telescope. It was an amazing experience!

A great way to learn about the Incas and astronomy. Our family really enjoyed this family run business. My children ranging from infant to 13 years old enjoyed the tour as well. It was interesting to hear about the history of the Incas incorporated in the presentation. The best part was being able to see Saturn and its ring using the telescope. We would highly recommend this experience!

Wonderful -- and accommodating to young children. We loved every moment of it. They were so great. They had blankets and music (although the live music may not happen every night, but I wish it did!). They joked with our toddler and incorporated him into the presentation hen he was getting fidgety. You can tell it's a family run operation by how nice they were. And the information is so great. When we got home, we started looking at the stars in our backyard, practicing what we learned in Cusco. We did a lot in Cusco, but this was by far our favorite thing in town. It's a must!

Amazing! Worth every penny!. A family run business that inspires you! It also gives you the history on why the stars, moon and sun were so important to the Inkas an how we now as a population have lost their importance. You view the stars inside in the dome built room and then then the images with a detailed explanation to why and where they came from. After you move outside to view several stars and images via telescopes. The highlight for me was viewing Saturn! Well worth booking and supporting this family run business.

Fun Way to Learn More about Incans and Support Family Business. This is a small, family run operation and they are all very knowledgeable. We learned a lot about how the Incans used astrology for agriculture and many other things. We were also taught about the constellations of the southern hemisphere before going outside to observe them. It was a great activity to do before visiting Machu Picchu!

Don't Miss!. This was excellent. It is shame that there is so much light pollution where the planetarium is located, but don't let that deter you. It is a very neat family, doing what they love and just so passionate about it. Dress warm as the temperature drops at night, the presentation is good fun, and the view over the city driving back is pretty amazing. Don't forget the "gift-shop" ...well there isn't one. but it helps support what they do and they have odd little bits for sale like a poster, coffee mug or stickers that my family got a kick out of and so inexpensive compared to all the stuff pushed to you in Cusco during the day. So if they don't offer anything up, ask, as they likely have something and it is for a good cause. I booked the "tour" through my accommodation, and it was a little disorganized waiting for the driver...but they found us and we all got to know each other while we waited in a very cute square just off the main square. The chocolate museum was just there, so there was something to help "pass" the time. I really enjoyed it.

Nice and informative. As an hobby astronomer I found this fun and informative. Got pointed out southern hemisphere only constelations, viewed two double star systems and Saturn. The planetarium session with the Incas dark constellations was nice. It would have been nice if the location to be further from the city though, we could see the milky way but I guess light pollution is ver hard totackle even in Cusco.
Amazing experience. This place is amazing, a must do while in Cusco. Inexpensive and the tour is awesome. Definitely recommend it

Must see attraction. I signed up for the planetarium tour and had the best time. We met up in a square located near plaza aramas. We then drove up to Saqsaywaman. I have to admit my expectation was to see a modern day planetarium, so when we drove up to their building I was at first taken aback. However, it was explained to us since they are located in a national park there are a number of regulations that prohibited new buildings to be erected. In any event, it was a good opportunity to keep an open mind. I'm glad that I did. The tour is broken up into three parts. The first part is more lecture oriented. The second part is in the planetarium itself. The third part ties both the first two parts together and how it relates to the Inca civilization. I won't go too much into detail, but I had a great time learning about the stars and how also the Inca viewed celestial spaces. The guy who gave the tour really loved talking about astronomy which made it more enjoyable for me. If you go to do a hike afterwards through the hills, it's really cool to know this stuff before hand. I would not hesitate to recommend this to anyone visiting Cusco. It's fantastic and one of the highlights for me during my time there. I also saw Saturn and its rings!!!!! so amazing!!!

Unbelieve experience!. First, let me just say that I am NOT a planetarium person. My friends and I were looking for attractions near Cusco and decided to go. Turns out, this was one of my favorite experiences during my time in Peru! This planetarium is run by a family and they are SO enthusiastic and passionate about the subject that it rubs off on you. Being on a mountaintop and observing the stars with and without the telescope was unbelievable! I would highly recommend going here--it is worth every penny and you will never forget it.
Nice guide and tour. The planetarium is small and they don't have big telescopes like I've seen in the US but the tour was interesting and the guide very nice! Price is reasonable.

A warm welcome and really interesting. We had a fantastic evening here. This is a family run business and you can really get a sense of their enthusiasm and willingness to share knowledge about the stars. The staff were really friendly and the presentations were great. We were lucky enough to get some great sights through the telescope before the cloud rolled in - we'll be looking for the little silver llama when we head to the sacred valley next :) Highly recommend this if you're in cusco! We had a little trouble booking through the system on the website, so would recommended emailing or whatsapping them directly.

Amazing. An amazing tour! They sit you down and give a talk on the history of the incas and how they used astrology in day to day life. Then you are shown all the star constellations in their dome room. When it's dark outside you have a chance to look at planets and stars through a telescope and also see all the stars. They provide blankets which help keep warm but dress for cuscos night time chilly weather! An amazing tour, well worth the money and they do student discount!

Stellar storytelling and stargazing!. The Planetarium Cusco was a surprise highlight of our trip. It’s a private family operation run by people who are truly passionate about the night sky and Peruvian history/folklore. The uncle/niece guide team used interactive storytelling to teach us about outer space and how the stars influenced the Inca people. A mini theater with a rounded dome displayed a projection of the night sky, where we reviewed the common constellations (some unknown to me in the southern hemisphere) and also learned the stories behind ancient Inca constellations. After the indoor presentation, they equipped us with blankets and hot tea to go outside for live sky viewing with their big telescope. Unfortunately the clouds of the rainy season were not cooperating, but amazingly the knowledgeable professor was able to reveal a bright star in Andromeda and Mars for us before we called it a night. Gandalf the dog was also a treat to meet. Absolutely wonderful. Dress warmly!

Great evening activity. This is a fantastic activity. The information presented on the southern sky is really interesting for those of us who live in the northern hemisphere, especially learning how the Inca viewed the sky. We got to look through a telescope outside afterward at several different constellations. They picked us up in Cusco at a central place we could walk to from our hotel.

AMAZING night out. THANKS ANA, you are a STAR ;). This one of our most enjoyable evenings out on tour to South America! Firstly and most importantly Thanks to ANA, she was really funny and most importantly she has a skill of turning a complicated subject like astronomy and making it fun and easy to understand. We viewed the cluster stars, Jupiter, Venus and Pluto all on the telescoped and also sat in a auditorium where Ana showed us the INCA science of astronomy which was really amazing. We learnt alot and had a really good time, Thanks ANA. You are a STAR ;)

The Big Black Llama in the sky. This is such a great hidden secret! Family owned planetarium with loads of pasion and humor. We were picked up just before dark from Regocijo square in the centre and brought to the planetarium just outside of the city. The tour had three stages, a story on the way the Incas used the stars and constellations, a moment to view different planets and stars outside and last but not least, a viewing in the dark dome where they reveal the western and inca constellations. Did you know the inca's had "dark constellations" existing out of the space between groups of stars in the milky way? All stages done with such love and dedication! I've been recommending this place to pretty much anyone heading to Cusco.

Great show and a good education on the southern sky and on Incan Astrological efforts.. Great show and a good education on the southern sky and on Incan Astrological efforts. This private and family owned planetarium does a great job.

A fun place to visit while in Cuzco.. I highly recommend a visit to the Cusco Planetarium early on in your stay. It is an opportunity to really gain an understanding of the stars in the southern hemisphere and how the science of the Inca coordinated to create a unique and highly advanced system for growing food and weather prediction. The opportunity to look through telescopes is an added plus and the planetarium show is packed with fascinating facts. You will enjoy it.

No frills, just a passion for the sky and all its wonders!. This is a wonderful place for everyone in your family. The staff (all relatives of the astronomer) are passionate, knowledgeable and speak English very well.Each member of our family (ages 11-58) enjoyed our visit.Very cold at night..bundle up!

Cannot recommend this highly enough!. Amazing experience run by an incredible family who love astronomy! Their casual approach to booking and picking you up at one of the squares in the centre of Cusco continues as they give you the whole tour before asking anyone for any money, it really did feel like their priority was that we enjoyed the experience and learnt all about the stars as the Incas saw them rather than simply a money making enterprise. And the stars are amazing out there!!!!

A fascinating variation to the normal planetarium. A must on any trip to Cusco, gives you another perspective to the archaeological sites. It's an interesting mix with maps of the constellation coupled with Incan astrology

A highlight of our trip. Totally loved our trip to the planetarium. Staff was wonderful..Great knowledge and very friendly. We had a clear night so we got to see many constelations we cant see here in N. America.

So simple, so modest, so nice. Family-run planetarium with small financial means by great love for astronomy and passion to share it. We found it by chance through this site and loved it. Very, very cold at night (July) so please, take a few extra jumpers and gloves and woolly hats etc. but definitely worth it. We had totally clear sky, had the good fortune to see Saturn with its rings and Jupiter with 4 of its moons, aligned as the best of military parades.They do a beautiful slide show inside before you go out to see the real stars and planets.

The best experience in Cuzco. We spent the most lovely time at this home made planetarium, we learnt so much and the owner and the writer of a great book is the very same scientist that will welcome to his most magnificent creation, the sighting of the abets and the stars with the understanding of the INKA cosmogony is just thrilling. Is a must to go in cuzco

A great look at the Inca sky!. My wife and I went to the planetarium upon a recommendation from our local guide and it did not disappoint. There were three steps to the tour: first a presentation on how the Incas used their knowledge of astronomy to improve their livelihood (especially in reference to agriculture); then a show in an indoor planetarium which exhibited various standard constellations as well as those that the Incas used (be careful not to miss the dark constellations, which are very special as few cultures ever used them!); finally we went out and took a look at some stars and planets. The whole experience was very enjoyable and the staff were great (it is a family business). Beware to dress appropriately as it gets quite chilly towards the end of the tour.

A nice way to finish the day!. First of all, BE ON TIME! They aren't kidding when they say they leave promptly. We nearly missed our ride, thanks to a bit of traffic. Despite still being a small facility, their enthusiasm shines through all they do. We had a great time being guided through the southern skies. Dress warmly!

Disappointing. It has been awhile since I visited this and I have never written a negative review, but this was very disappointing.What I thought were a few pictures in the waiting room was one of their main features. Also, there were 8 people attending the very cold night and we had to wait to get a glimpse of the telescope We couldn't wait for the night to end so we get into a warm taxi and get something to warm us up.

Great Experience. Loved the staff....Was a little chilly during our visit and they brought out blankets for everyone. Very knowledgeable, entertaining and hospitable. Must see during your stay in Cusco

Nice evening out to see and hear about Inca astrnomy. Joined this tour to see the stars from the Southern Hemisphere. It was very interesting, they had Spanish and English guides to explain abut the Incan astronomy and also show us some of the constellations like the zodiac animals. Unfortunately the sky was a bit cloudy but we did see some stars.

Pretty Impressive!!!. I have to say, this experience was pretty fun. I have always loved astronomy and star gazing, so this was a must for me. This family run planetarium was pretty impressive and very informative. My 7 year old really enjoyed it!!!

Lesser known attraction in Cuzco. The planetarium was a great value couple of hours and worth searching out. It is family run and they are very enthusiastic about astronomy and sharing this with the visitors. The pick up is not at the main plaza and is a little hard to find but they seem to work it out.

Intimate Yet Professional Planetarium. We reserved a few spots with this site for a last-evening-in-Cusco experience. We were delighted by the family, the planetarium dome, Gandalf, Jose, and the star gazing with his uncle. Every effort is made to make guests comfortable. What we learned added to our knowledge gleaned from various visits to the archaeological sites. Despite shifting clouds, we were able to see Saturn's rings, Jupiter's moons, Venus, numerous star clusters, the southern cross, and more. It was a fun and intimate setting and well worth both the fee and the time.

run by a family that loves their work. loved the personal touch. We were in a large group but they made sure that we all had opportunities to use each telescope and ask any questions. It's a small planetarium but a lovely excursion.

Great experience. Great family business. Learnt a lot about the southern hemisphere and the inka history. Everybody was enthusiastic and really liked to teach us something. Even got a pickup from the city
Magical evening. We had a fantastic time - even though it was a cloudy night. The family are wonderfully accommodating and really informative.

Erwin and family are important archeoastronomer outreachers. Totally recommend it.. I have so many things to say about this planetarium, that I don't know where to start...Let me begin saying that I am a professional astronomer and I totally recommend the visit if you, too, can value the work of a man and a family that have no support at all from the government to pursue their research and promote science education and outreach. If you are expecting a full dome digital planetarium theatre, then just don't go. Save your planetarium visit to some other place in the USA or Europe. Cuzco planetarium is a family business run by passionated local amateurs astronomers trying their best to spread their Inca cosmovision knowledge. As a professional astronomer, and an astronomer curious on the field of cultural astronomy (ethnoastronomy, archeoastronomy, etc.) I have no words to express my gratitude to have visited Cuzco Planetarium and the opportunity given to learn with Erwin about his findings on Inca astronomy. If you are going with kids (5-10yrs), believe me, they will totally love it.If you are passionated by astronomy or amazed by how the Incas used astronomy on their daily life, you will also loved it.If you are more interested in a cinema-like planetarium, then skip the visit.

Learn about Inka's science. Nice, funny presentation about the Inka's science, how they observed the stars and the seasons through structures.They predict what and when to plant, that made them so strong.After this, we have presentation of the southern star maps, and went out to see them in real.50S pick up / drop off is very nice price for this.

Best weeknight activity in Cusco . We heard about the Planetarium on a whim and decided to try it out on a free night in Cusco. We were incredibly impressed with the experience and the amount that we learned about Incan history. Would recommend to anyone.

Very Accommodating. Ana Maria and her family were extremely accommodating, providing myself and several study abroad students with a wonderful experience on a Sunday evening (when they are typically closed). Everyone was extremely friendly and knowledgeable. If you are looking to do something that is outside the typical "tourist" activities, make sure to include this experience during your stay. Highly recommended!

Passion Generations Long. This little planetarium is well put together and driven by the passion of an entire family. A self made dome, a presentation hall and a series of telescopes to see the sky for yourself. If you're into space, or this is your first time in the southern hemisphere, go here. NOTE: You have to make a reservation, something that I missed on their website. Regardless, they were accommodating.

Great Family Business. I went here because I wanted to learn more about constellations in the Southern Hemisphere. When the evening started I was worried that the planetarium was not going to impress me but it really did. This family-run business is small, but they have impressive telescopes and a star dome. Before the clouds rolled in we were able to see the binary stars at the bottom of the Southern Cross as well as Saturn (its rings!) and Titan. Inside we learned about how Portuguese sailors named the southern constellations. Most interesting to me was the stories about the Inca constellations- especially the black llama! I thought it was a great evening in Cusco and I would recommend going- especially if you have an interest in the stars.

Simply Amazing!. We loved every minute of our trip to the planetarium! We had a clear night and so were able to see tons of stars through the telescope. The presentations inside the planetarium were so informative and fun! Thank you so much for a magical night under the stars of the Southern Sky!

Amazing what this family-run Planetarium can do. We were so impressed by this little family-run Planetarium and how much knowledge and passion they have.This was easy to book. If you call on the phone or email, service is prompt and English is good.Pick up and drop off to/from the Planetarium appreciated.The brief lecture in the beginning was inspiring.Very impressed with the quality of the telescope used for Star-gazing. And the time in the dome with the story and information we received equally impressive.If you're at all curious about learning more about Incan history, astronomy, and the universe, this is a go-see attraction while you're in Cusco.

Stellar Experience :). Planetarium Cusco completely exceeded my expectations! My parents and I (I'm 17) visited in early June, and we had a beautifully clear night, which I understand is pretty common this time of year. The planetarium is family-run and it feels like it- we were welcomed by three family members bearing warm blankets, and Gandalf the dog. There are three parts to the experience- a lecture on the history of Incan astronomy, stargazing outside (using a telescope, we saw the Jewelry Box Cluster, a globular cluster, Venus, and Jupiter and its four Galilean moons), and a tour of the zodiac and southern constellations in the dome. The family members were welcoming, funny, and well-informed. I would definitely recommend this experience!

Amazing!. This was such a fabulous way to spend an evening! We have a teenage budding astronomer and she and my husband and I found the entire evening fun, informational and inspiring! We had a very clear night and so in addition to the introductory presentation and the presentation in the planetarium, we were able to go outside and see the Jewelry Box Cluster, a globular cluster, Venus (which we could also see with the naked eye), and Jupiter and its 4 biggest moons - all through an impressive telescope. It was also fun to see the Southern Cross and all the new constellations in the Southern Sky. We would DEFINITELY recommend this activity!

Awesome Evening, Super Informative, Lots of Fun!. I read about the Planetarium Cusco in my travel guide, and when I saw the picture of the Inca astronomy at Qorikancha, I knew we needed to go to the planetarium! You do need to make a reservation, though they were able to squeeze in one extra person. We made our reservations just a few hours in advance, and it was totally seamless. They picked us up in the square across from our hotel, with the rest of the group and drove us up to the planetarium, which is near Sacsayhuaman, overlooking the city. The building itself is small but cozy, which was wonderful on a chilly night. We started with a brief history lesson about the Inca civilization and how important astronomy was to them. The woman who was presenting was fantastic, super informative and approachable. After the history lesson, we went outside and used two telescopes to look at Jupiter, the moon, and several beautiful stars and constellations. The night sky was incredible, and the staff did a great job pointing out the main constellations and giving us plenty of time to enjoy them. They even brought us hot tea!Then, we went back inside and had the chance to experience their lovely planetarium, with Western constellations, and then the beautiful Inca constellations. All-in-all, a memorable evening with lovely hosts. I would definitely recommend this to anyone before hiking in the area. The best part was being out on the trail and looking up and identifying so many of the constellations. Absolutely breathtaking. It's easy to see why the Incas were so involved with the stars. A must-visit while you're in Cusco!

Wonderful tour of the night sky. We didn't have a chance to make a reservation, but they made room for us anyway. Funny and friendly staff picked us up and showed us the wonders of the southern hemisphere. They spoke excellent English and showed us a half dozen things in their telescope, explained many significant Incan astronomical phenomena and then invited us to the planetarium to explore some artificial constellations.This was such a fun and unique experience for us. Really great!

Stood us up :(. I arranged a tour with Planetarium Cusco three months in advance. They requested that we switch out date so we did, and agreed to meet at the regocijo square at 6:40 pm.We waited for thirty minutes and even had a nearby store call them for us but there was no answer.Very disappointed in their lack of professionalism and communication.

Great family run operation. We had a fun time at the planetarium despite it being cloudy and not a very good night for stargazing. Very well organized transportation and presentation. We learned about modern astrology as well as the astrological beliefs of the Incas. Very interesting material and it was cool to see the virtual dome projection of the southern sky.

Fun, family run evening's stargazing. A great and fun way to spend the evening.It is also a great way to familiarise yourself with the stars and constellations in the Southern hemisphere, prior to a trip on the Inca Trail or other areas of low light pollution.The presentation gives you the opportunity to see the stars projected onto the dome of the planetarium and then to physically go out and see them through the telescope.The family are very friendly and present everything with a sense of humour and fun. They are also very accommodating and and give you blankets to keep you warm on the colder evenings.Trips can be booked in advance and they will pick you up from the square.

Has to be alright on the night. Good meeting and presentation given in three stages. I was unfortunate that it was a cloudy night but learnt a lot about El nino and the dark constellations. Quite a treat really, but a bit steeply priced. I would advise to do this before trek to get the most value from the information given.

A Must Do!. In anticipation of our camping towards Machu Picchu, I booked a visit to the Planetarium for my husband and I. We are Northern Hemisphere folks so I was looking forward to seeing the Southern sky. We were picked up from a central location in Cusco and driven up to the Planetarium (appropriately situated away from lots of light pollution) and met by some friendly dogs. It was, obviously, very dark and it's an uneven hill down to the building so be warned. The family who runs the planetarium are delightful folks. Uncle Erwin is the man behind the telecopes and was a sweet man. He queued up some telescopes outside on real stuff and whenever I leaned over the eyepiece he'd say something like, "Take your time, really enjoy it." You can tell he's a space buff and wanted to share that love with others. His niece was the one who lead our little group through the indoor planetarium section. She was also a lovely woman. Sure, we saw some cool planets (we also had patchy clouds that night) but it was the people that really made the visit. This family is doing something they love and their enthusiasm comes across to visitors. And now I get to look for the Black Llama in the milky way!

Great experiance!. Even with their private budget, family run Cusco Planetarium is a treat for stargazers. They know so much, and show so much personal interest and enthusiasm! It was hard to leave!Very good organisation with the transport from the centre and back.Thank you for you excellent work! Great people who love what they do, and is happy for sharing, is worth much more than any government grant =)I could recommend this also for families with children from maybe age 10 and upwards, the stars in the sky is fascinating for any age.

Amazing.... Having researched this Planetarium, before our visit...we were fortunate to enjoy and appreciate the 'clear sky'...the presentation by Professor Cavazos and his Niece...was truly, an amazing experience. Discovered so much more about constellations below the Equator...
What a night.. Fantastic evening, picked up in Cusco. Excellent knowledge of both hemispheres, inca and modern astronomy. Made to feelVery welcome in a very homely observatory.
Great experience!. Coming from North Europe i am used to different view of the stars. Everything gets explained. Staff is extremely passionate and helpful!

great place!!. the professor erwin has great knowledge , is fun and i got really good information , also i went with a group of friends and the sky was very clear , was a great experience i got to see saturn !! was so exciting.

A MUST in Cusco! . An excellent family owned initiative located 12 minutes away of Plaza de Armas. The whole experience takes between 2 to 3 hours. Try going before visiting Machu Picchu or the Sacred Valley, since there is plenty of helpful information that would add to the experience and knowledge of Inca history. Totally recommend it!!

Very Interesting!. It's a great thing to do before you do the Inca trail, the staff were super friendly and created a really nice atmosphere, you can feel their passion for the night sky. Reasonably priced and worthwhile to support this family business.

Don't miss this!. If you come to Cuzco, you will visit all the traditional touristic site, but I highly recommend non to miss the visit to the Planetarium! It's a great experience and a very interesting way to understand the Incan astronomy and cosmogony and you'll learn how the incan sites were strictly connected and aligned with stars. Inca had an amazing astronomic knowledge and their lives were related with sky, earth and nature. Discover all about this great ancient culture at the Planetarium!

Hidden gem. One of the highlights of my trip to Peru - a real hidden gem. We learnt things about the Incas that countless other tours didn't tell us about. A wonderful, peaceful and charming night. Great family business doing something brilliant with passion and knowledge.

one of the best things. takes you out of the city for an amazingly informative view of the night sky, you feel like you're in the country, and the guides were young, well informed, and seemed genuinely interested, which made it great for us too.

Space, Stars, and a little bit of history. Wasn't sure what to expect, but this family run planetarium really knocked it out of the park and were even able to do it with their rustic setup. You don't need anything fancy to talk about the stars and the influence that it had on the culture in Peru. They go into a lot of the details of how the constellations were named and the stories behind them. After the presentation we went outside and used their telescope to see the stars, planets and even a galaxy (blew my mind!). We also got lucky since there were only 3 of us, so it was a bit more personal and we could ask questions, etc.Great little side trip if you have time..worth it.Thank you!

A planetarium in the city!. Who knew this existed? Apparently a lot more people than I would have thought. This attraction is actually listed in the Lonely Planet book although the price has increased since then (50 soles).Well worth a visit if you are into space, even if you are not it is pretty cool! They talk about the history behind the sky both from a modern perspective and from the Incan point of view.After some talks, they bring you to the planetarium portion of the building which is a rounded dome where they project the sky with the constellations and talk about how there is a different set depending on the hemisphere that you are in.Then they take you outside and show you a few stars (clusters, double stars, and even stars you cannot see without a telescope). We also got to see Saturn which was pretty cool.The experience is very enjoy and will last roughly 1.5 hours. If you have some time in the evening, this is a very neat attraction.

So worth the visit. Thank you for such an informative and wonderful presentation. The stories alone were worth it, but to connect the inca with modern astronomy was sweet. The presentation was stellar and we just loved it. It was uber cool to see the southern stars which we normally don't get to see! Best...

Amazing!. The guys who ran it were very interesting and passionate, there was the right amount of information and looking at the night sky with the telescope was fascinating! A must do in Cusco if you have any interest in the stars and the Incan´s relationship with them.

Amazing storytellers. This is a small, humble, family run business in which an uncle and nephew lead presentations that detail how the incan people interacted with the night sky. Presentations are offered in both Spanish and English. Both presenters are extremely inspiring in the way they speak due to the passion they have in the subject matter.

Awesome night sky!!!. It felt like the sky was so close at the Cusco Planetarium making this well worth the price and something I definitely recommend while in Cusco. We met Ana Marie at the Plaza Regocijo and were taken by the planetarium's van to their site. Be sure to dress warm as you are outside part of the time. We were greeted with Coca tea and given blankets but it was a bit cool on the September evening we were there. We started with a brief lecture explaining the constellations and what the night sky meant to the Incas. Once the lecture was complete, we went outside to where we were able to observe stars and planets through their telescope. Afterwards we went back inside for a virtual guide of the stars in their planetarium room. I had never seen the southern cross before, but was always able to locate it on clear nights during the rest of my trip in Peru.

Under the Stars!. Our tour to the Cusco Planetarium started with being picked up from one of the squares. After a short 10 minute ride we arrived and were greeted warmly. Our guide was very informative and passionate. You could feel her energy and enthusiasm during the presentation. Afterwards we stepped outside (dress in warm clothes as it gets pretty cold) and were given hot tea and blankets. We observed various stars, clusters and planets through the telescope. It was well worth the price and would definitely recommend it.

Very Educational!. At 12,500 ft the evening sky is almost touchable making the Cusco Planetarium is a must visit. The cost is 50 soles per person or 30 soles for students (~$18US). Your experience starts are Plaza Regocijo which is the very next square from Plaza de las Armas and where you are picked up by the planetarium's van. They are very punctual. When you arrive, you are greeted with Coca tea and their doggy. Depending on the sky that evening, you are given a brief lecture explaining the constellations and what it meant to the Incas.
