Once the lecture is complete, you either go to the telescopes, or enter the planetarium room for a virtual guide. Unfortunately for us, we were in Cusco very briefly and the night we picked to go turned out to be overcast. The staff is very nice, and if weather conditions don't allow for a telescope view, they grant you another visit, free of charge, so you can come on a clear day. Our stay did not permit for another day, but it was nice to know we had this option.

A must while in Cusco. I have never been into a Planetarium, I made a reservation by mail, they answered promptly. They recommended dress warmly, so I didWe were 22 people and everybody thought it was one of the highlights while in Cusco CityProfessor Salazar is an amazing person, full of knowledge of the stars and a very funny and friendly person. Ana Maria makes a perfect match to her uncleDo go, you will be happy that you did it.

So great! . I really enjoyed my experience at the Cusco Planetarium. Highlight was seeing Saturn through the telescope. This is the real deal! Bring plenty of layers if coming in the cold month of August. They provided hot tea when we were outside. This organization is privately funded. Support them and help keep this organization going. Pick up was about 6pm and drop off around 8pm. Side note: my Lonely Planet guide quoted $30 soles but I was charged $50 soles. Not a huge deal but bring extra cash in case.
Under the stars. A great evening with very enthusiastic and funny people, who share a lot of interesting informations about the stars.
a must see. this is a must see, these people are so nice and the whole thing is just really a great evening, you gt use telescopes, have the incan cosmology explained, real nice people!

Fun thing to do in Cusco. We visited Cusco and went to the planetarium show one evening. They pick you up with a group of 10-15 people and drive you up the mountain. This is not a real planetarium like you think of in the States, it is a family business and their building is a little log cabin. They tell you a bit about Incan history and why astronomy was important. They also have a domed room and project the stars on the ceiling and show you the shapes of the constellations and their meanings. Then you go outside and they have a big telescope, maybe 4 ft. long and show you maybe four stars and everyone takes a turn looking at them. The cool thing was some of these stars you can't see from the Northern Hemisphere. The staff was very nice and offered everyone fleece blankets. It was very cold! Highly recommend bring a ski jacket or a winter coat of some sort. This was a fun thing to do, but not mind blowing. I think some of the other reviews exaggerate a bit.

Excellent experience. Enthusiatic staff. And an Awesome dog called Gandalf.. A short but excellent 1.5 hour experience hosted by the kind and enthusiatic staff at the Cusco Planetarium who were keen to share their passion for and knowledge of the sky. The tour began with a presentation on how the Incans understood the sky followed by a walkthrough of the various constellations. Afterwards, the Director of the Planetarium showed us what the Moon, Saturn, etc. look like through a telescope. The Planetarium also has a super friendly resident dog called Gandalf and several lammas.Tickets were 50 s./each.

Brilliant friendly place. Great evening. The family run planetarium is very interesting and they are clearly very passionate about what they do. It does get very cold. They have blankets but wrap up warm before you go.

Loads of spirit!. I loved our visit to the planetarium! It is run by a family who are SO SPIRITED and excited to share their knowledge - fun and hilarious! Learnt a lot, but didn't feel like you were in a lecture theatre. The tour picked us up in the Plaza, on time. Had a quick bus trip up to the planetarium and then started the tour which was three parts. Part 1 - star maps and story telling in the domePart 2 - outside, looking through telescopesPart 3 - back inside for more storiesIt was freezing when we went but they bundle you up with nice fleecy blankets.BONUS: they have a lovely flea less labrador called Gandolf. Worth the visit - good for older kids too.

Cusco Planetarium. The panetarium was unique. I didnt enjoy the experience but that doesnt mean you wont. If you ar interested in stars and whatnot then its great for you. Otherwise you might find yourself literally falling asleep like I did. The staff (family owned and operated) was extremely nice and very knowledgeable as far as I could tell. If your a student you get a 20 soles discount. Overall I didnt have the best time but definetely worth a try if you think you might be interested in it.
Beautiful little spot outside cusco. I highly recommend going to the planetarium. The guide was great and it was wonderful to learn about how the Incans interpreted the stars. Dress warm!

A Little Bit of the Heavens. Really loved the amount of information received from our very enthusiastic host. Amazing what a telescope will reveal that the naked eye can not see. Loved seeing the Southern Hemisphere sky.

See the Inca's stars, understand their reality. If the Incan buildings and beliefs seem impenetrable in their mysteries, this experience will help you make sense of their perspective. It really helped me.

An awesome celestial experience. Viewing the southern sky for the first time, high in the Andes, is unforgettable. The constellations were brilliant and we looked at Jupiter's rings and moons through a telescope. Maria is really enthusiastic and entertaining, and her planetarium show indoors included the Inca constellations (llamas, naturally). Wrap up warm!

Great night. I definitely recommend doing this. It's very cheap and really interesting, especially if you are remotely interested in astronomy. The two hours were spent learning about the night sky and stars, the Inka's interpretation of the stars and stargazing outside with a hot cup of tea. Ana and her uncle are lovely people. We got ripped of for 40 soles at the travel agency where we booked the trip, and Ana promised if we didn't get the money back, she would personally go down there and get them back for us. Definitely do this, it is a different experience from what you usually would do on your travels.

Fascinating experience!. Ana and her uncle present for just under two hours with an impressive combination of knowledge, enthusiasm and wit. I emailed the planetarium in the early afternoon and received a prompt response confirming availability for the evening. The presentation is given in English and Spanish. It begins with a projection of the cusco sky at night onto a domed ceiling with Ana and her uncle showing all of the visible constellations. The presentation then turns to the Incan constellations and the importance of astronomy to the Incan people. The tour concludes outside viewing constellations and planets through their telescope (blankets and mint tea supplied).

Enthusiastic/Great Background on Incas and the Milky Way. This was the first 'tour' of our adventure in Peru and it was a perfect choice. Ana Marie provided great background and information on the Incas and how they used the stars for agriculture. It gave a great foundation for the rest of our trip and the amazing places we would see. When we arrived the night was cloudy and we thought we were only going to be able hear the lecture and see the planetarium but like clockwork the clouds parted and we were able to look thru the telescope. We saw Jupiter with it's dark bands and 3 huge moons, Mars, the Souther Cross, double starts and even other galaxies. We even saw 2 shooting starts. This was a wonderful experience. We loved it!!! Don't miss it.

Interesting explanation of Incan astrology...... Thoroughly enjoyed my visit to the cusco planetarium. The pick up service was prompt and efficient. Ana Maria had me enthralled with her passionate explanation of the Incas and their association of the stars with their agricultural practices. The dome was beautiful. Unfortunately it was cloudy when it was time to view the stars however the planets aligned (so to speak) and the sky cleared. The professor showed us Jupiter, Mars, clusters and galaxies. His enthusiasm was infective. Blankets and warm tea were a lovely touch. A great experience which I highly recommend.

HORRIBLE SERVICE. My sister and I made a reservation with the planetarium. We waited at the meeting point for forty minutes after the meeting time (and we were there 20 minutes early) before returning to our hotel. When we returned to the hotel we phoned to determine why the planetarium employee did not show up. She said she was there. The planetarium employee did not announce herself or move around the small square to see if we were waiting for her despite our reservation. We had planned our day around the outing and wasted a significant amount of time. Don't waste yours.

Amazing. This was one of the best things I have done in Peru! Intimate group, and the most enthusiastic guides! Learned so many interesting things, was fascinating to learn about how other cultures used and interpreted the stars. Great value. My only advice: wear LOTS of clothes, it was freezing!

I would give this more than 5 stars if I could. Picked up in town. This was one of the best experiences of my two weeks in Peru and I am not an astronomer. The enthusiasm of the owners was wonderful. I saw Jupiter through their telescope. It was cold. A starry night which made it good but cold. They provided blankets

Spectacular Night. We thoroughly enjoyed our night under the stars. Blankets and hot tea warmed us from the inside out and the information and star gazing were out of this world! A must do whilst in Cusco!

Charming & informative. Ana Maria is delightful! We arranged to visit the Planetarium via email with her. It's not in Cusco, but about 10 minutes outside. Conveniently, they pick you up in one of the town squares for your evening visit. Out at their cosy farmhouse/observatory, Ana Maria explained the Incan views of astronomy and the heavens, and how it influenced agriculture. Then we went into the dome (!) for more information and an introduction to the constellations of the Southern Hemisphere. Outside, we observed Jupiter and its moons through the telescope, and enjoyed visiting with their dear dog Gandalf. Plus blankets and tea! All these facts were incredibly fun and helpful when seeing ruins and stars along the Inca Trail. Highly recommended!

Cusco skies explained beautifully. I loved this delightful planetarium tour! Astronomy has played a big role in Peru and we were informed very entertainingly and visually about the constellations and history at this lovely planetarium!

So much information about incas and the southern sky. This was definitely one of the most interesting places i've been. The people are extremely enthusiastic about the stars, they are proud on the incaculture and will tell you all about it. I've learned more here than in any other museum in Cusco. It was also a really nice opportunity to see the stars and planets and the moon through a telescope, I don't know much about astronomy so everything was new to me and awesome to see Jupiter so close.

Enthusiasm makes up for low tech. The astronomer who runs this family business clearly loves his work and his enthusiasm for astronomy is infectious. They opened up the small but totally adequate planetarium for our family, showed us the constellations and night sky over Cusco, gave us information about Incan constellations, and then we went outside to look through a telescope at planets, nebulas, and stars. It was fun for our family of four (kids 12 and 14). Dress for the outdoors!

Down to earth. Very enthusiast and knowledgable staff! the professor really shared his passion. Witty family owned planetarium. A modest operation add to the charm of the place they will pick you up and bring you back to a well known plaza in the center of town. blankets and tea offered to cozy up in the (potential) cold of cusquenian nights. Loved it!

I don't even like astronomy and the lesson was fascinating/a fun trip for my kids. This was one of the highlights of our time in Cuzco. We had a great time together as a family and overall both kids enjoyed themselves tremendously (ten-year old was fidgety during the initial part that was lecture-based). We each got a little blanket with stars on it to help keep us warm, we saw Jupiter through the telescope (they made sure to rush us out when the sky was clear to ensure we saw Jupiter before the cloud cover might have prevented it). The instructors obviously knew a lot and were friendly, with one providing English translation since the majority of the group we were with spoke Spanish. They provided round-trip comfortable transportation from the Plaza de Armas. I think serving hot chocolate would be a plus for kids, as neither drank the tea. Dress warmly. It's a lot of fun and a great experience in a beautiful location just outside the city.

Great pre-machu picchu activity. My friend and I learned so much about Machu Picchu and andean culture during this cozy class. We liked the dome, blankets and tea too. My only suggestion is to light up the stairs with a flashlight. It's cheap, effective and prevents falls.

Interesting facts, enthusiastic host, not cheap so it's your luck if it rains.... We decided to visit the planetarium based on the great reviews on Tripadvisor although this place was not listed in Lonely Planet's SA on a shoestring. It turned out that this was not the wisest financial decision as the cost of 50 soles/ pax was a tad too expensive, given that we didn't get any actual viewing of the stars due to the rain. The 1hr+ presentation was rather interesting with a good introduction to Incan astronomical beliefs, plus Ana Maria is a very knowledgeable, friendly and engaging host. While the weather is beyond's anyone's control, we felt that the planetarium could have reduced the entrance price of 50 soles by at least 10-15 soles as a matter of goodwill when it rains. I also think if the group is big (10-20), the price should also reflect the time one gets at the telescope.

Peruvian Stars. My wife and I were in Cusco last April. Very last minute we decided to visit the planetarium. They were flexible with their hours and stayed open late for us. A driver met us and we drove up the beautiful hillside to a quaint planetarium where we were greeted by Ana Maria, our host. Ana Maria had a vast knowledge on the Peruvian sky and it's influence on the ancient and modern cultures. We saw star formations through a telescope and sat under the cold stars with blankets while drinking hot Munya tea. Sitting on the Cusco hillside we had great discussions on the Inca, their agriculture, and it's influence from the stars. This was a very intimate and unforgettable experience.

Ok but could be better. The Cusco Planetarium have friendly and enthusiastic staff but the program could be better. I think the cost (50 Soles) is a bit high for the 1 1/2 hour presentation but the pick up and drop off was nice. The program included quite a bit of time in their dome on constellations but when we went out side they didn't point out any of the constellations they discussed inside. We only spent about 10-15 minutes outside actually looking at the stars. The lighting from the neighbours made seeing things difficult.I am interested in astronomy and found the program mildly interesting but I have no idea how it could be rated as the 8th best attraction in Cusco.

A great experience in Cusco!. The Planetarium is definitely a place to visit during your stay in Cusco. It is run by Ana Maria and her family, including their cute dog, and they really do their best in order to give the visitors all their knowledge as well as their sincere passion. For this reason they did organise the visit even we were a group of three people, while they usually organise visits for at least six people. All the explanations are comprehensible even for those who are astronomic illiterate and they make you discover a new world! Since the Planetarium is quite far from the center, they pick you up in town and they drive you till the Planetarium.

Enjoyable different experience. I found this to be a nice experience. The fact that this planetarium is so different from what you expect makes it very special. Located in a small rustic cottage by the hills where they give you a presentation and teach you about the starts and constellations projected on a dome. Then, you go outside (gets cold but they provide warm blankets) where you can look at the beautiful open sky and see the moon, stars, and galaxies using their professional telescopes.The organizers' passion about their ancestors and astronomy quickly immerses you into it. If you have the time, this is an experience to remember.

Fun experience!. I really enjoyed my time learning about the Southern hemisphere's night sky. They will pick you up in the small plaza beside plaza de armas and take you to their facilities just up on the hillside.There are three aspects of this experience:1) First thing you do is learn some interesting facts about astronomy and agriculture and the Incas,2) Next is find out how to navigate through the night sky and some fun things to look out for and also how the south compares to the north sky.3) You'll get a chance to look through their telescopes at clusters, the moon (which is actually super cool!), venus, and other things that may be up there depending on the weather conditions. Although it's not a government operated planetarium (so don't expect some super advanced equipment), the organizers (who are super fun and enthusiastic as noted by other reviewers) definitely make up for it and you still get to see amazing sights!It's a very fun alternative to going to a bar; I only wish that I had been able to go when I first arrived rather than at the end of my trip.Tip:- If there is something you want to see in particular, let them know and they will try to find it for you in the telescopes.- It can get cold, so bring your warm clothes! They give you hot tea when you're outside using the telescopes.- Their communication is very good; just send them an email with any questions!- They pick you up around 5:30PM and drop you back in the plaza about 2 hours laterIts not super cheap (s/50, s/30 for students/children), but if you budget for it, it's an enjoyable excursion you should try!

Best memory of Peru. I'm going to begin by saying you HAVE to do this.The enthusiasm of the lady was incredible for starters, she has so much passion about the stars its highly addictive.Before you look through the telescope, the Northern and Southern Hemisphere constellations are explained. This is then followed by what the incas believed and gazed at.When we went outside to look through the telescope I saw the Milky Way, the moon, Venus and a double star. Unbelievable value for money. Easily the best thing I have done in Peru, if not South America.

An evening under the stars. The enthusiasm these people have about stars (and dark spaces between stars) is absolutely contagious. They put such an effort into showing you the splendors of the night and explain how important star gazing was for agriculture and the success of the Incas. Seeing the moon through their telescopes is breathtaking. One thing that would be nice would be to have a brochure of some of the highlights/where to look for things as it all happens so fast and I have since tried in vain to remember the different things they told us about specific stars.There has been some confusion about the price. The price was 50 soles per person (as of September).I would definitely recommend this unique experience.

Really excellent. We went based on the prior reviews and were not disappointed. This is a lovely family-run business and a really nice way to spend an evening in Cusco. We enjoyed all aspects of the visit - from the informative intro, to the star gazing, to learning more about the constellations under the dome. I'm pleased to say that I can now identify Venus, the Scorpio constellation, Alpha, Omega, etc.

Quite possibly the best attraction in Cusco. The Planetarium is quite possibly the best attraction to be found within the city of Cusco itself. A short 20 minute ride up to the Reserva ecologica de Llaullipata brings you to a very different looking planetarium from those you may be used to. This however just adds to the charm of the place. The guides are spectacular, extremely knowledgeable in what they are presenting and incredibly passionate about what they study. Their good vibes and enthusiasm only add to an incredible experience. To top things off, you get to see both Saturn (something I never thought I'd see) and the moon through their telescopes outside. Something in Cusco that cannot be missed!

I will never forget how much I loved this experience.. This is a wonderful, family run, friendly, informative and fantastic value experience.You can see the moon and Saturn and more through the telescopes, learn about the stars, Incan history and how they used and interpreted the stars, hear stories and snuggle up under a starry blanket which is provided.All information is provided in Spanish and English, and you are collected from town and taken in a safe and comfortable minivan to a beautiful setting for a wonderful experience.I loved this place beyond words.

A really enjoyable experience. The hosts were very welcoming and had great knowledge of the night sky. The talk was interesting and the planetarium show was great. Luckily we did get to do some stargazing before we were clouded out. The location was very convenient and getting picked up and dropped off in central Cusco made it all so easy. Well worth it.

Inca night sky a totally new experience. Wow, this really blew my mind. Who knew the Incas looked at the dark parts of the sky to find their constellations, rather than the stars? It was also so fun to look through the telescope at the night sky for real. This is a great, great attraction.

Nice way to spend an evening. The visit was very well presented by very enthusiastic and friendly owners. We were lucky to have visited on a clear night although looking at the stars outside was only part of the attraction.

Fun and well-done experience. This was a nice, different way to spend an evening. The guide was very knowledgable, and the tour was interesting and interactive. There was a short lecture, some time in a state-of-the-art dome, then some telescope time outside. Although it was cold, there were warm blankets provided. Seeing the stars of the Southern Hemisphere and Saturn (and understanding their significance to the Incas/knowing what we were looking at) greatly contributed to the overall experience. Definitely worthwhile.

best sketchy van ride of my life. Don't let my title dishearten you, it was a very nice van that took me to a very nice place! This planetarium is family-run and quite small, but it packs a big punch in the way of astronomy, especially explaining how the Inca and the Spanish viewed the Southern sky. I learned a lot in a short amount of time, and my group had lots of fun viewing projections of the constellations and then using telescopes to look at them. The staff was helpful, friendly, and kind, and if that isn't enough to convince you to come here, they also have a gigantic white dog named Gandalf who just wants to cuddle and talk to you. Also, they have stickers. Vive la Planetarium Cusco!

Meet Gandalf!. The Planetarium experience was good, it has a dome to project the night sky and Andean constellations. You can also see stars outside the planetarium with their telescopes, you can even see Saturn and its ring if you're lucky. They also keep a really cute huge white dog called Gandalf. You have to meet Gandalf!

very interesting. Good to get to know the southern hemisphere and to get info about how the inka used the constellations for agriculture. The staff is super friendly and the telescopes of great quality.

fun night out. We were a few days from heading out on the Inca trail, and the idea of seeing the southern sky from camp is part of the appeal. Planetarium Cusco is a small family run business whose love of astronomy and the history of the way the inca saw and used the night sky is apparent in every part of the experience. We didn't have the clearest night, but we made the most of it to see saturn, the ring nebula, and several other astronomical sights through telescopes, as well as a planetarium show about the southern constellations and the unique inca 'dark constellations' that can be seen in the milky way. there was also a brief talk on the significance of some of the inca ruins as astronomical sites. the only negative thing i could say was that i wanted even more of that.

nteresting, educational and worth a visit. Did this on our very first night in Cusco as were too out of breath to do anything else :) And very pleased we did. Got picked up from the town centre and taken to a house on a hill just 15mins outside of town. Started the star gazing with an indoor lecture about stars and astronomy importance in the Incan culture. Have to say I was really impressed about the energy and enthusiasm the the lady put into that lecture (bearing in mind she probably does that every night) and learned so much not only about the Incan astronomy but also the culture, history, politics and Peru climate. All very interesting and informative. The theory was followed with some practical peeking into the telescope outside, allowing to look at different stars. Was blown away by seeing Saturn through telescope (and even got a sticker at the end to say I have seen one :)) The nights in cusco are cold so we were given blankets and cups of warm tea, which was a nice touch. All in all - very interesting, educational and worth a visit while you're acclimatising for anything more strenuous.

great evening out. collected from plaza regocijo at dead on time and taken above cusco towards sacsayhuaman into the hills where a little establishment lies hidden away. here the enthusiastic staff gave a talk and demonstration about the southern hemisphere stars before we headed off outside to see the real thing whilst clutching a mug of warm tea. a small scope was set up outside and gave us amazing views even of the rings of Saturn which was visible the night we were there. minor downside was confusion over price quoted (25 soles pp) when price was 50 soles pp, but didn`t detract much from a fascinating and enjoyable evening out.

A must!. A friend of mine organized a visit to the Planetarium. I agreed because I had nothing else to do, and so I had no expectations at all. A van picked us up (very punctually!) from Plaza Regocijo, which is located only one block from the Plaza de Armas. When we arrived, I was surprised as it is not exactly the type of planetarium you expect. Actually, it's just a little house up in the hills, near Saqsaywaman.We were about 15 persons, half of them spanish speaking, the other half was an english speaking group. But that was no problem at all, we had 2 guides so we split up into 2 groups. I was in the spanish speaking group. Our guide, a Prof. who is also the director of the Planetarium, explained us a lot about the Inka's and their relation to the stars, the universe etc. It's just amazing what the Inka's already knew about the whole universe. Actually one could say that their whole culture was connected to the stars, our sun, the milky way...the Professor explains this amazingly good, and you will be fascinated from the first minute he starts talking!After a lot of interesting explications, you will have the possibility to have a look trough their telescopes. We were able to observe Alpha Centaury, the second "nearest" sun to the earth, the lower star of the "cruz del sur" constellation and as a highlight planet Saturn with his moon Titan.If you don't come here, you will definitely miss a highlight of Cusco!

Great little family business. Really informative and interesting. The staff do really well with the basic equipment. Not far from town and the transport is good. I would recommend before going up to machu picchu.

Great experience; enthusiastic staff. A group of ten of us went on this great trip, and it was worth every penny. The staff is knowledgable and highly enthusiastic about the content. The small planetarium is intimate and informative, and their equipment is good quality. I would highly suggest going, if you have an evening free.

How can I make a reservation?. My family and I will be in Cusco end of this month and the planetarium seems to be a interesting place to visit. Can anyone tell me how I can make a reservation? Their web site is not working. Thank you for your help in advance!

Planetarium cusco. My friend and I did this on a whim and really enjoyed it. You have to call ahead because space is limited and they only go three days a week. It is a family run operation. They gave a nice talk about the Incan culture and then we went into an indoor planetarium and stepped outside to view the constellations and some stars. It was nice to apply that knowledge in the following weeks to continue to find stars and constellations on the dark inca trail and in the jungle

A fun, unique experience with wonderful hosts!. You are picked up in the center of Cusco in a comfortable van and driven 15 minutes up the hill near Sacsaywaman. Nightly shows include a presentation about Incan history and culture through the lens of astronomy. Then you visit the planetarium and get a review of the constellations with a focus on the southern sky. There is also a slideshow that shows theIncan constellations including the dark constellations. Finally, you go outside and look through their very good telescope. We saw the Omega Centauri globular cluster, binary stars , and an excellent view of Saturn.The hosts are incredibly gracious and enthusiastic making for a fun and unique experience. They give you a lap blanket on arrival and serve herbal tea.

Very interesting and enjoyable. We absolutely loved the Planetarium in Cusco. Very knowledgable staff. Interesting facts and fables about Incan astrology. And a look at the night sky through a telescope - AMAZING! It was a freezing night in Cusco, so I recommend you wear warm clothes (although they do provide blankets and tea).

Don't Miss the Planetarium. Looking through the telescope we could see Saturn and the rings around it! Our host spoke excellent english, they also provided hot tea and blankets. It gets darn right cold in the evenings in Cuzco.

Excellent!. My husband and our two children (ages 7 &9) visited the planetarium this evening. It was as amazing as all the reviews suggested. The sky was overcast when we arrived, but by the time we finished learning about the constellations (in the dome) and the Inca sky, the clouds cleared. We had an amazing view of the southern cross and we were able to see the rings around Saturn with the telescope. My children especially enjoyed Gandolf, the adorable white dog that lives at the planetarium (the only dog in Cusco we allowed our children to play with). All of the staff was amazing, we enjoyed our mint tea and blankets. The building does not appear to be a planetarium from the outside, but don't let the appearance fool you. Remember to bring cash, credit cards are not accepted. This is a must see if you are visiting Cusco!

So much fun!. This was a highlight of our trip. The staff are very knowledgeable and kind, and their enthusiasm is infectious! We learned so much that helped us as we tours Machu Pichu and the Scared Valley. Definitely recommend you check it out, well worth the value!
Awesome. This was truely a great experience. The staff were friendly and fun and it was a special thing to be able to see the stars in such a unique setting.

The trip to Cusco was made perfect by this experience. This was a lovely experience. The whole family is engaged in the effort to educate visitors about the Andes, the Inca skies, and astronomy. The enthusiasm they project is unmatched, and the little touches make this a perfect experience (they pick you up at Regocijo square, when you arrive you are given a blue stars-and-moons patterned fleece blanket, and hot cups of mint tea to warm you up while you stargaze). Also, there is a friendly white dog named Gandolf to keep everyone company!I feel so lucky that I heard about this and would strongly encourage anyone traveling to Cusco not to miss this. It is the perfect outing between a trip to Sacsayhuaman in the afternoon and before dinner (you finish with the stargazing around 8 or 9). You will feel invigorated by this family's passion for the skies!!The current charge is 50 soles ($18 US) which is a complete bargain for a 3 hour rich experience, transportation included.

Southern Cross and other constellations!!. My family of 4 including a 20 and 18 year old loved this sight! We were picked up by a van and taken from the center of the city to the plantetarium which is close to the ruins. We loved the education and experience of seeing the stars on such a clear night about Cusco. Also, we were able to see Saturn with its rings from the telescope! awesome

Very good. We were unfortunate to go on the one overcast night during our entire so was unable to use the telescope, but the tour of the building was very interesting. I would recommend it, as even without the telescope the Cusco sky is unpolluted and crystal clear, making stargazing an amazing experience.

A must-do in Cusco. My sister and I were the only visitors the night we went to the planetarium. We were picked up at our hotel and transported to a lovely setting. The indoor presentation was informative and interesting with diverse information about Peru and the Incan culture included. The outdoor star gazing was marred only slightly by an overcast sky with occasional glimpses of the Southern Cross and other stars and planets. I strongly encourage everyone to visit, before or after your excursion to the Sacred Valley.
Impressive Planetarium. Modern Planetarium- our kids loved it- Very clean and comfortable and a must do if you have interest in this type of activity

Unique experience stargazing. This is my first time to the Southern Hemisphere so when I heard about this planetarium I knew we had to try it.It was very convenient-they picked us up and dropped us off in Cusco. We especially loved going outside and learning about the night sky. I saw the Southern Cross for the first time, as well as other constellations like the boat and mosquito. Through the telescope they showed us Orion Nebula, and Saturn, among other things. I had never seen Saturn's rings before- kudos to them for showing us such wonderful sights!The whole experience from pick-up to drop-off was just under 3 hours, with 2 of them at the planetarium and about 15 min each way driving. Highly recommended.

Outstanding night sky experience. We had a fabulous visit at this wonderful attraction. They picked us up at one of the main squares in Cusco, took us to the planetarium site, just as the sun was setting. The very enthusiastic staff provided an entertaining and informative description of the southern hemisphere night sky, the Inca view of the heavens, and even the agricultural and political context! Then we saw wonderful things in the night sky through their telescopes, and an entertaining planetarium show with a lovely emphasis on Inca mythology. A perfect evening outing in Cusco that beautifully complemented the Inca Trail trek we set out for the next day.

This was a pleasant surprise.. We decided to go to this after reading a couple reviews. it was interestig to book, you need to call in the morning to set up your visit. They instruct you where to meet and then they come pick you up at that location to visit the Planetarium. The briefing they give you basically gives a lot of insight into the ruins and the significance of the things you see at the ruins.it turned out to be one of the best things we did to understand the history and agriculture in the Sacred Valley.i'd recommend this to anybody. Wre from Seattle Washington area so we've never seen the Southern Cross Constellation. We got to see it from the Planetarium as well as a few others in the Southern Hemisphere.

My daughter and I thoroughly enjoyed our experience. The staff at the Planetarium was very nice and very enthusiastic. They provided us a lot of interesting and hands on knowledge about the Incas and how they used the night sky to help found a civilization. It was a fun and different experience.

A beautiful experience. The staff at the planetarium is very friendly, knowledgeable and passionate about what they do. That translates to the audience immediately. They care about your comfort and provide you with warm tea and blankets on cold nights. They also indulge your questions and speak to you and either Spanish or English depending on your needs. This is a great activity for families or for adults who love to stare at the stars. My favorite part was learning about the Incan constellations. The only recommendations I would have would be to purchase stronger telescopes (I'm no expert but I have seen the rings of Saturn from sea level with a telescope in the everglades, in my mind that makes me think that at an altitude of over 11,000 feet I should see a clearer picture of Jupiter rather than what looked like zooming in on a star) whenever possible and to arrange for a darker setting in which to enjoy their knowledge and the beauty of the skies. I understand their limitations and with those mind I believe they do the best they can with what they have and that this is a great experience for a clear night in Cusco.

Unusual way to spend an evening learning about Inca constellations. A wonderful little gem in Cusco City. The bus picks you up early evening from one of the squares and takes you to the planetarium on the hill side overlooking the city. First an introductory talk (English and Spanish options done separately) which was wide ranging about the history of the stars and its uses - for example in agriculture. Then we went outside where it had got very dark very quickly and had a wonderful session star gazing. The hosts used laser pointer pens to pick out constellations and planets. This was excellent as no matter how hard I have tried in the past I have never picked out anything more than Orion's Belt! Next the big telescopes came out and the very knowledgable and passionate professor picked out some of the best sights in the night sky - including Jupiter and the Orion nebular - where stars are born.Finally a presentation inside the planetarium dome showing the constellations with helpful pictures overdrawn and an explanation of the inca astronomy of dark constellations which was fascinating. It was very cold but we were provided with plenty of blankets and we were impressed with how the trees had been planted around the site to minimise the light pollution from the city - very effective. An excellent evening costing 50 soles each which I highly recommend to anyone before embarking on the inca trail to learn a few basics to appreciate the night sky along the trail.

A wonderful experience, don't miss it!. Located high in the hills above Cusco, (the drive itself was beautiful) we were thrilled to observe the night sky, free from the lights of a big city. Through their telescope, we were able to observe different planets and the moon, very clearly. It was amazing to be given an explanation of astronomy from the point of view of the Incas. Very friendly, enthusiastic, very kind. Go!

A must!. Great place to visit before visiting the inca ruins in Cusco! :) they are also very friendly and they offer you some coca tea and blankets if you feel too cold. Better to go visit around winter time where the sky is clearer.

One of the best attractions in Cusco. If you even a passing interest in astronomy, science, or the advancement of the Inca civilization I highly recommend this site! You have to meet the van at the small square adjacent to the Plaza de Armas and then you will be driven to a remote location (don't worry!) about 15 min away. My wife and I were there with another family so it was a small gathering and quite cozy. It's best if you can aim for a clear night's sky for the star gazing but with the usual hectic travel schedules this is not always possible.The staff there are passionate about astronomy and are very easy to talk to. They made a wonderful presentation and handed out blankets/hot tea as it is quite chilly at night. After the presentation they take you outside and show you different stars/constellations and how they were used by the Incas for predicting seasons, rains, etc. I actually got to see Saturn and the Moon through the telescope which was amazing. This is enjoyable for all ages.

A wonderful educaitonal experience. The Cusco Planetarium is a delightful addition to the overall cultural experience found in this part of the Andes. My wife and I were delighted by the presentations especially the opportunity to view several southern hemisphere deep sky objects through the telescopes at the Planetarium site.Of especial note is the care the presenters gave to describing Inka constellations, which are mostly "dark or black" constellations produced by dust clouds obscuring stars in the Milky Way. I would have preferred to hear more about those (the resident astronomer, Prof Salazar is an expert on Inka constellations and star knowledge). Northern hemisphere astronomy buffs should not miss the opportunity to see the glories of the southern skies....and so close to town (but with minimal light pollution)! Some of the astronomy knowledge presented (intihuatanas, the Oyanti pyramid, the Q'enqo "awakening the puma") will be invaluable in enhancing visits to nearby Inka sites including Tipon and Machu Picchu.Prof John Stocke, CU Boulder astronomer

Excellent!. Our family of 5 were the sole visitors to the Planetarium Cusco one night during the first week of January. I had my doubts as our driver neared the site (and seemed to keep getting lost), but they were all dispelled from the moment we arrived. We were greeted by the staff of 3 with soft blankets and a cup of tea to ward off the chill night. We spent the next couple hours entranced by the presentation! When it ended we went outside and were thrilled to have a chance to see Jupiter through the telescope, even though the clouds were significant. Our 3-generation group learned a lot, and also appreciated spending time with people who so clearly love what they do. It was a very worthwhile side trip for us in Cusco.

Fun and informative, book last minute and make sure the sky looks clear!. You get picked up from the square besides the Plaza de Armes and it is about 15 minutes up to the location. Housed in a converted barn there is a talk on the stars and how they were used by the Incas (at least their best guess) followed by an interesting show in the small planetarium. The best bit was seeing the stars and moon through the telescopes outside afterwards.The kids loved it. Just make sure it is a clear night. Expensive by Peruvian standards but not bad by western prices.

Fun and worthwhile experience. The planetarium is a really fun experience! It's a privately owned planetarium run by incredibly passionate people. While we had the misfortune of fog (as is often the case), we did have a lovely time hearing about the Incan mythology, exploring their planetarium theatre, checking out the moon with their high powered telescope and seeing the view. What a breathtaking view above Cusco! Transit is super easy (they pick you up from the Plaza and deposit you right there).

Nice, but cloudy.. Since I went during the rainey season, it was very cloudy. The couple gave a nice explanation and tour, but they didn't turn on the telescopes while I was there due to the clouds. I really wish they turned it on just so I could see.

Raining but still great. A small family run planetarium that explains (in your native language) how the Incas saw the heavens, and why. We were there on a rainy night and didn't get to peer through the telescopes, but it didn't matter, the presentation and exhibits were very earnest with a lot of pride for the Inca culture, and helped explain some of the things we had seen at Maccu Piccu.

check the cloud cover before visiting, generally great eveninig. do check the cloud cover and what interesting observations you can perform on the night you plan to visit the planetarium. the visit there starts with a bus ride up to the Sacsowouman hill from Cuzco. then there is a short lecture on Peruvian sky, methods of observations and Machu Picchu's parts. then we sat for a show of starts in their own in place planetarium cinema. at the end of the visit, weather permitting, we looked at some cool places on the southern sky - we saw a nebula where the stars are born!

Good, but not great. Excellent service. First of all, don't try to get there by taxi. They have a transportation system, use it. Because I didn't have much time in Cusco and had already booked several activities, I tried to get there by taxi. The taxi driver had no idea of where it was, charged me 15 Soles (all rides in Cusco cost 4) and almost didn't find it. Overall, it was a very good experience, the service is great, just don't expect much of the scientific part.

Stars aren't just for dreamers. This is a small, private company operated by very passionate and friendly astronomers approximately 15 minutes away from Cusco - don't expect anything too grand, but do be happy that you are investing in a local business and cause.We went to this planetarium before doing the Inka trail, and though it didn't help us recognize constellations too much, it did confirm how important the stars above were for the Incans - both in terms of their faith and for agriculture. It was especially interesting to learn how the Incans were the only civilization to also have "dark constellations."We were a small group of 4, which nicely felt like a private showing. Unfortunately, the moon was almost full the night we went so it was pretty hard to see many stars. If you're flexible, I recommend visiting when the moon is least bright. We also didn't spend as much time outside looking at stars or planets through the telescope as I would have liked. Perhaps if we had an even later start time, we might have possibly been able to see more. Alas though, so much of visibility is contingent on the weather and the moon.The student discount costs 30 soles which made the experience affordable. Their dog, Gandalf is the sweetest dog I met in Cusco (and I met a lot of dogs there), and all in all, how can you not enjoy staring at the stars?Don't forget your sweater! It gets really chilly.

Stars like you've never seen in your life!!. WOW - what can i say - i saw the surface of the moon through this telescope!!! I saw the rings around saturn!!!!!!!!! YIP- through this amazing telescopeSaw the South Star - the Southern Cross and a few other constellatioins - their names evade me at the moment!!THe stars here as absolutely AMAZING - all twinkly like you could almost reach out and touch them!Dont hesitate in going here - just book it - you will not be disappointed!!! AMAZING!!!

A must do in Cusco.... My wife and I went along to this after seeing an entry for it in Lonely Planet and it's high rating here on TripAdvisor. Neither of us are stargazers, so we didn't really know what to expect. We arranged the trip incl. transport for S50 each, which is pretty reasonable.We got picked up later that evening and brought up to the planetarium, about 15 mins from the centre of Cusco. We were in a group of about 10 people which was a nice number. After a brief introduction into how the Inca's viewed the skies and some examples of this, we were fortunate enough to be brought outside for some live stargazing through their telescopes. I'd never done anything like that before and was really struck by this part of the trip - Mars in particular looked amazing through the telescope.After looking at a number of different interesting features in the night sky, we went inside for the planetarium which again was pretty amazing. I can't complement the staff here highly enough - their enthuasism for what they do was contagious. Even their dog, Gandalf, was one of the friendliest dogs I've ever had the pleasure of meeting.

Informative, Funny, and Passionate. There are three components to the Planetarium experience: 1) A informative talk2) Dome projection of night sky3) Telescope experienceThe talk was charming and interesting, providing just enough information for my inquisitive mind, but not too much that I started zoning out. Always a fun experience, I love planetariums for the projection presentation, I was at first disappointed as we were presented with the more well-known western astronomy bits and constellations, but quickly perked up as discussion on the Incan astronomy and astrological myths began (my favorite part!) Sadly, the clouds weren't cooperating and we missed out on telescope use that night, but I imagine that would have been lovely as well.The family's passion for the stars and their heritage definitely comes through with a high level of warmth, consideration, and intelligence. However, a few suggestions:1) It's cold in there, is there not anything at all they can do to warm the place up? (Bring your mittens and hats and scarves!)2) For those needing English translation the dome projection experience was at times difficult to follow (at times the Spanish and English overlapping one another), I am hoping over time they can smooth out the kinks in the presentation 3) Just a bit of hands-on or interactive experience would be lovely - especially if the telescope experience is not happening due to weather!Overall, lovely experience - highly recommend it! :)

Amazing Little Museum. Tiny museum but so well done. Excellent explainations of how Incas used stars and sun alignment in their lives. The guide was very personable, and looking through the telescope outside was really fun.

Great experience. Based off other TripAdvisor reviews, we decided to come here and were not disappointed. Keep in mind the planetarium is a private business and not a public observatory as you would expect in the US. The day we were scheduled to go, it rained and they were more than willing to accommodate and move the tour to another evening which had better weather. Transportation to and from the planetarium was easy and seamless since they picked us up and dropped us off. The evening starts at around 5:40pm and ends around 7:45pm. The tour is in 3 phases, 1) short lecture where you learn about the history and importance of the stars to the Incan people, 2) going outside and looking through telescopes at the stars, and 3) coming back inside for a brief presentation in their observation dome. The evenings are cold in Cusco, and they gave was hot tea and warm blankets for when we were outside looking through telescopes. It was really interesting and helpful especially since we would be going on our 4 day Inca trail hike to Machupicchu and would be able to take that knowledge with us as we star-gazed at night. Overall, a great experience and an activity that can easy be done in a short evening.

Interesting Evening Lessons. We were picked up at promptly 6pm and taken to the Planetarium. We had no expectations of the place and had time to kill. I enjoy watching people who are passionate about what they are doing and I don't think you will find anyone as passionate as the Professor and his niece. Also learnt a few more things about the Incas and Cusco, which is always a good thing. We went at a time when the sky was cloudy so we did not see the stars at all but the nice thing about the Professor and his niece was they invited us to visit the following day to see the stars, alas we were leaving then.

Great way to fill in the evening. We did the planetarium for something to do one evening. Being from the Northern hemisphere, I had only heard of the Southern Cross but had never seen it until going the the planetarium. Also, I had never seen the rings of Saturn except in pictures. The professor who owns the planetarium is very passionate and excited about astronomy and gets a kick out of showing off the different constellations and planets.

The best way to connect the dots how the incas knew about astronomy and agriculture.. If you still have doubts about the way how the inca's cities were built. You will find your answers in a great atmosphere followed by a cup of tea and a night sightseeing telescope. By Adriano Giannella

Fun and interesting. We got lucky. When we arrived at the planetarium, it was cloudy. Throughout the (interesting, information) indoor portion, it stayed that way, but within 5 minutes of going outside to use the telescopes, the sky cleared up completely and we had some amazing views. It was my first realization that I was outside of the northern hemisphere for the first time, as I saw constellations like the Southern Cross. I even got to see Saturn and it's rings. Definitely recommended as a fun evening activity before a late dinner.

Fun to look through the telescope. The family that runs the planetarium is incredibly friendly and helpful. They go to great lengths to make you comfortable in the cold (blankets and tea included), and are very enthusiastic. The indoor presentation didn't have too much information, but really I think that's because most of the information about the Inca is unknown. Much of what they share is stuff you will hear elsewhere while traveling through this area. The best part was looking through the telescopes at the star clusters and Saturn (which was cool, but as you would expect, brief.) If you don't have much time in Cusco I would probably skip it.

Very interesting. Great night, learnt alot, staff are excellent, gandolf the big friendly dog is beautiful. Best part is the viewing of Saturn through the microscope. Recommend to anyone even slightly interested in the skies or the incas
great thing to do in cuzco. interesting, super informative, great to visit with kids, they have a ver organized visit and they pick you up at the plaza in cusco, reasonable price also

An introduction into Inca astronomy: just plain amazing.. After reading the gushing praise about this facility on Trip Advisor, we booked a night with them while in Cusco. A van picks up the group (ours was about a dozen or so) on Plaza Regocijo, located just a block or so from the main square. It is a ten minute drive to the planetarium proper.The evening presentation is divided into three main sections over two hours. First, a twenty minute introductory lecture is given reviewing the role of astronomy in Inca culture and its role in helping make decisions regarding religious offerings and crop cycles. Various storyboards are used during this time in addition to a 3-D model of the solar system. Next, the group is taken into the planetarium (indoor “artificial sky”) where a professor of astronomy displays various constellations from both the northern and southern hemispheres and continues basic concepts begun during the first lecture. Lastly, weather permitting (we had crystal-clear skies), the entire group goes outside to see various planets, stars, and constellations on professional telescopes. These machines aren’t the usual rickety contraptions on tripods but the real deal; I saw the rings around Saturn and Mars for the first time in my life! Attention to customer service is superb throughout the entire process: blankets, tea, and goodwill are in abundance throughout your stay until your return to Cusco about two hours after arriving.Later in our trip, we could put a lot of the information to good use when hiking the Inca Trail the following week when the Milky Way and Southern Cross suddenly became identifiable (and therefore meaningful) instead of functioning as passive sky ornaments. Other topics such as the role of the summer and winter solstice kept popping up while we were at Machu Picchu. As perhaps the biggest compliment to the family who organizes this, I just recently purchased my own (very amateur) telescope and will be watching the moon through its phases next month.An overall excellent experience: inexpensive, well organized, useful, and entertaining.

great introduction to Inka and pre-Inka culture. My wife and I visited here soon after arriving in Cusco--while getting over jet lag and adjusting to the altitude.....a wise choice, since it wasn't physically taxing.The young lady who made the initial presentation was enthusiastic about talking about Inka contributions to the world. And the gentleman was so thrilled to show us the southern sky and how it figured importantly in Peruvian cultural thought through his very powerful telescope. Another group was supposed to join the two of us, but they didn't show. No problem. We were given a "private tour" with no extra charge.This was a wonderful experience and a terrific introduction to what we were later to see in the Cusco area.

Calling anyone interested in science. Cusco is filled with cutural attractions. This is the only science one, and its great. We didn't need an organized tour, the two of is just called the number on their website and got a spot that night. They picked you up and drop you off in the main square. Everything was really nice, the presentation was wonderful and we leaned a ton. Worth the $. Do it before your hike.

Don't miss this if you have time!. I have lived in Sao Paulo, Brasil for over a year now and never did know where the southern cross was, but now I do, thanks to the education I received at this wonderful family run planetarium. I can also pick out several other constellations found only in the southern hemisphere. We saw several planets through the telescope and other interesting things. I would recommend you spend the time to learn a bit about the southern sky and Inka history...

Very Enjoyable!. We did this tour with kids, ages 6-15. The tour was interesting and entertaining, and the 3D diagrams were really cool. The tour guide is very passionate about her work, and explained everything, although here or there you miss a word because of the tour guides spanish accent. The blankets and hot tea they served when we went outside was a nice touch and kept us warm when we looked through the telescope outside.*Recommended for children ages 9 and up*Slightly expensive (50 sole for adult, 30 for child)

amazing experience. Had a private tour of the planetarium with my 8 year old son. It was one of the highlights of our time in Cusco. LOVED looking through the telescope at end of program. Saw rings of Saturn and several other stars/planets. Chilly outside while viewing - but, they provide warm blankets and hot tea!

Passion!. I liked so much this tour, the planetarium is a family business and they are really passioned about their job giving us the best they can, explaining everything about Inca's astronomy and the southern sky!

We enjoyed it. We chose to do the Planetarium the night before our Salkantay trek so that we could use some of our new knowledge on the hike. We were told we were going to be picked up in Plaza de Armes on the stairs of the Cathedral. We happened to notice that they were having a parade in Plaza de Armes and all of the streets were shut down. I asked my hotel to call them to confirm our pick up point. They tried all of the numbers but the people in charge were not around and kept telling our hotel to call back. About 30 min prior to leaving our hotel finally speaks with someone who agrees with the traffic and has us meet them somewhere else. They showed up 15 minutes late but there was a lot of traffic. We were dropped off at a small home about 15 minutes from our pick up point. It was very cold and they had a lot of people there that night. They handed out blankets but did not have enough for everyone. The lady who spoke had very good english and you could hear her passion behind her stories. They bring you into a dark circular room after the introductions and explanations where they show you constellations on the ceiling. This was actually really nice. Everyone in our group though wished they could have shown each constellation by itself so our imaginations could visualize it better. After the dark room, we all went outside to look into the big high powered telescopes. Clouds were starting to roll in, so we could only see a few constellations. The southern cross was very beautiful. We were also shown Saturn and you could actually see its rings!!! That was awesome. During our trek, we would look up and find ourselves finding all of the stars and constellations that they taught us. We had to leave a little early since we all had to be up at 4am the following morning. The lady said that the van was dropping us off at the hotel, but we were dropped off in Plaza de Armes and had to walk 15 minutes back to our hotel.

Best tour ever.. So this trip was really awesome. Ana told us to meet in Plaza Recogocito and the bus showed up exactly where it was supposed to. It was kind of hard to miss since they had a a decal on the side of the bus. It actually showed up on time and they waited for about 10 minutes after 530. Ana was really nice and she spoke very good english. We learned a lot of interesting things about the stars and how the Incas interpreted the sky. The sky wasn't cloudy so we got to see a lot of neat stars. We actually got to see Saturn which was like, unrealsies. The visit to the planetarium definitely was a highlight of my trip - and I've seen practically everything here.

Waited for an hour to be picked up. Nobody came.. This was the second tour in Cusco that we really looked forward to, without anybody showing up. We made reservations via the website, but didn't get any reply. A day later we called, and got the information that the contactform on the website doesn't work.So why do you put it there?We made reservations and were told to be in a small square next to the big Plaza de Armas. We waited there for half an hour and then decided to call the numbers on the website. One was picked up by a very young girl, who could just say that her mother was not home. An other number was picked up by a tour agency, who said they couldn't do anything for us. Another one wasn't answered.What is it about Peru that you get unclear directions about where to be, you wait for an hour, and in the end nobody show's up? A big disappointment, we were really looking forward to this. And unbelievable how businesses are just fine with disregarding tourists like this, that are willing to pay 50 soles per person. And have a 4 year old girl picking up the phone while people have been waiting in the cold for an hour.A big blemish on our stay in Cusco.

Definitely a must when you visit Cusco. Excellent for a family vacation... We and our kids learned a lot about the Inca's relation to the stars... Also we could see a beautiful setting with a great presentation.

The Incas had a great understanding of the universe. I found it interesting the way they called the milky way the celestial river .with all the animals drinking from it coincidence we have animals too like leo cancer &the zodiac,&that was pre colombian.!?funny.

One of a kind experience!. This was such a fun activity during our trip in Cusco. We learned so much about the Incan culture and also about astronomy in general. The hosts were so welcoming - giving us blankets and warm tea while we were outside star-gazing. The tour was delivered in excellent English and the hosts were SO enthusiastic about what they showed us - their excitement was contagious. It was so easy to contact them via email and they set up transportation for us from the main square. I can't think of any way they could improve this. Highly recommended!

Great evening experience. This was a last minute discovery for us and what a lovely little gem! Highly informative and insightful - would strongly recommend a visit, especially on a clear night as the star/planet gazing is quite incredible. Van pick-up was from the main square, where we were taken up to the tiny planetarium in the hills behind Cusco. Hosts share a wonderful passion for Inca astronomy.

Interesting and informative. The site is small but informative. The Tour is divided into three components. The first section is informational with exhibits, section two is in the dome where you can see the constellations! and section three is outdoors with the telescope. Unfortunately section three didn't happen on my visit since it was cloudy! Will definitely try to go back when I return (for section two and three).

Enjoyable evening in cusco. My boyfriend and I went to the planetarium this evening and really enjoyed it. Gives a great background and insight into the incas and their beliefs and methodologies. Hosts were very welcoming and knowledgeable. Recommended!

My favourite Cusco attraction. My 2 best friends and I found this on trip advisor and decided it was a must do prior to our PeruTreks Inca Trail 4 day hike as we all loved planetariums and star gazing. We were travelling the month prior to arriving in Cusco, but Ana Maria was very efficient and we were able to organise a tour via email. We waited at Plaza de Armas, and the driver appeared at the appointed time. We were driven up the mountain to the Planetarium. What initially looked like a little farm and shed out the back, quickly gave way to a a quaint observatory, informative charts and awesome telescopes. The presentation on Inka astronomy, the links to agriculture, practical usages and integration with culture were fascinating. It helped us understand what we saw along our trek to Machu Picchu. Bring warm clothes as it gets cold at night (gloves, hat, scarves, warm jacket: layers are best), camera, you may find a small torch or headlamp helpful for seeing where you are walking. They do have a torch but it is hard to see after dark. Don't let the simple appearance fool you, the information is well researched. Our Spanish is terrible, but Ana's English is excellent and understanding the wealth of knowledge she presented was not a problem. Look closely at the 'pierced drum' which is used to shine the constellation onto the inside of the dome. The family were so thoughtful, they brought us hot tea and blankets to keep us warm whilst we were star gazing through the telescopes outdoors. Would highly recommend this to all ages, and that visitors organise to do this soon on arrival to Cusco. The 2 to 2 and half hour experience was over all too quickly
stars. I have been to a few of these in europe.. but i like this one best.. very quaint.
Great evening, very interesting. We had a wonderful experience at the Cusco Planetarium. Learned a great deal about Inka Astronomy and enjoyed a beautiful view of Jupiter.

The simplest and most exciting planetarium I have ever been. I like visiting planetariums in my trips. The interesting point is that although this is the simplest planetarium that I have ever visited, it is at same time the most interesting one. It is a family enterprise (or at least seems to be so). You will have at around one and a half hour class of the Inca astronomy (and comparisons with the mainstream astronomy) with people who really love what they are saying to you. Also, depending on the weather conditions you will see the stars through good telescopes. I have not seen this attraction in any traditional guide, just through trip advisor. I recommend the planetarium to anyone visiting Cusco who likes planetariums. Anyway, it is interesting to go only if you have more time in your visit to Cusco.

An excellent introduction to both Incan culture and astronomy. As an astrophysicist, I was incredibly impressed with the facilities that the planetarium had-- without any external funding, they managed to build a planetarium bigger than my former university's, and had several telescopes set up for outside observing. It was much more than just a planetarium show, with a detailed background of Incan astronomy and its uses both inside and outside of the dome, along with the night-time observations of several planets and deep sky objects. They also were able to schedule an affordable private show for two people (as we were there during a time with few tourists); they are also bilingual, for non-Spanish speakers like myself. This institute provides a much needed introduction to cultural astronomy and acknowledgement of the wonderful contributions of the Incas to the field.

An amazing evening. I went to the planetarium as the only English speaking person in the group and was to feel really comfortable. The introduction and explaination was fantastic, especially how little Santi translated everything that Ana was saying perfectly. Although it was too cloudy to see the stars, I still had a wonderful time

Amazing!. We went to visit the planetarium on the 30th and had AN AMAZING time. We were explained what the sky meant to the incas and then we learned how to spot different constellations. As the sky was clear we were able to see the moon, orions belt, subaru and jupiter. We were so lucky the weather was perfect! We were able to take a picture of the moon through the microscope and it came out PERFECT, we could actually see the moon's craters in the picture!! If you want a glimpse of what you can see, go to their facebook page, we've tagged them on our picture!

Eye opening and culturally valuable. These guys went out of their way to get us to the Planetarium in time for the show. To the point that they arranged a special driver to take us there, the rather dignified and eloquent Founder of the Planetarium himself! We were SO glad they did. This tour is a very complementary way to understand the Sacred valley and its deeper history, through the eyes and the skies of its own native people.

not what I expected. Let me start by saying that this is interesting but not the highlight of a trip to Cuzco, since just walking by the central plaza or going to Saccsahuaman and watch the city from a high hill is more impressive. I like the idea of watching the stars on the south hemisphere and I thought this place has its own beauty but it should not be one of the most attractive attractions of Cuzco.

Planetarium Cusco was the highlight of our stay in Cusco!. We called Ana,the planetarium guide, at 5:00 pm on her cellphone and at 6:00 she, Robert, and Professor Salazar picked us up in Plaza de Armas to take us up to the planetarium. We four were the only people with a reservation, but they were willing and eager to share their wealth of knowledge with us!Ana told us interesting stories about the Incas, the skies of the southern hemisphere, and about the history of Cusco, the Incans, and Peru. All of us (ages 13-70) were very intrigued by all that she taught us.After the introduction, she took us into the planetarium for a terrific demonstration of the stars, constellations, and the Incas' interpretations of what they saw in the sky. Professor Salazar has put a great deal of research and time into making a terrific presentation, and Ana did a wonderful job of explaining it to us in English.The entire project is obviously a labor of love! I highly recommend this as an activity to do in Cusco, especially before you journey to Machu Pichu.

Sweet fun place, learned a lot, great experience. My friends and I were all meeting in Cusco before commencing a lodge to lodge trek to Macchu Picchu. One of them found this, thought it would be fun our first night. Wow, so glad she did, it was perfect! Drove up the rural road from Cusco, we immediately all knew we were in for a treat. In the age of digital high tech everything, we all really loved and appreciated how old fashioned this planetarium is, yet we did not need high tech to see and appreciate the constellations in the southern hemisphere. I particularly loved the Incan constellations, the black llama, rainy season, just fascinating. I felt like we were with family, during the demonstration. They passed out night-moon fleecey blankets to all of us! We then wore them outside when they passed out hot mugs of tea and we took turns checking out Jupiter and its 4 moons through the telescope, stunning!! It was the most perfect way for us to all gather, enjoy something fun, learn about Cusco, Incan history, enjoy the stars and the hospitality!

Despite altitude adjustment and jet lag, whole family enjoyed it!. This was our first activity in Cusco, just a few hours after arriving. Our hotel recommended staying in to acclimate, but this was the perfect activity for the evening. We met on the street and were driven up to the small but very cute planetarium. This is not a fancy or high tech operation, but we loved it! I particularly liked the low-tech, but incredibly useful and informative exhibit about the stars that form the Southern Cross constellation. This simple exhibit of foam balls on fishing wire explained the position, size and relative position from the Earth of the stars in the constellation in a way that I found more effective than the fancy CGI animations you'd see in a high tech planetarium. The best part was viewing Southern Hemisphere stars and constellations outside. My husband is on the board of a Northern Hemisphere space museum, so we see a lot of high tech stuff, but this museum was charming and interesting without all the bells and whistles...and even our tech savvy 13, 13, and 10 year olds were interested and completely enjoyed themselves (again, despite jet lag and altitude adjustment!). Highly, highly recommend!

A passionate review of the night sky. This family owned and run Planetarium is the prefect mix of technology and hospitality . We learned about the constellations planetarium-style, and then got to see the real ones outside with the help of Annie and her uncle (excellent English is spoken). This was a special treat for our group as we were all from the northern hemisphere and had never seen the southern sky! Annie gave us blankets for outside stargazing to fight off the night chill, AND while we were viewing Saturn, brought us hot tea! Annie and her family are knowledgeable and passionate and it is contagious. This was one of my favorite activities in Cuzco.

Beautiful evening explanations. Cups of tea, blankets, storytelling and telescopes - a great way to spend an evening in Cusco, and the perfect thing to do before the Inca trail - impressed our guide with our knowledge gained the evening before, and pointed out Scorpio to our fellow hikers. Fabulous introduction to the Inca world.

Great introduction to Inka worldview and Southern Hemisphere skies. This is a great thing to do early in your trip to the Cusco area. If you come from the north, you're going to want to know what you're looking at in the beautiful starry skies when you're out in the Andean countryside. Plus, a careful study of the stars was crucial to Inca science and religion, and forms part of the great architectural achievements of the Inca empire. This is a very friendly, informative, enthusiastic and energetic family-run operation deserving of much support. They adapt their talks to the ages, interests, and languages of the audience. Added benefit, they pick you up downtown and take you back downtown, so you don't have to find the place yourself at night.

A fantastic evening, I learned and saw so much!. I had contacted Prof . Erwin Salazar after seeing his Youtube video about the Pisac site (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WRkoKM-iABI). He met my mother and I at the planetarium's departure point where some other people were waiting. We were whisked off to the planetarium's site near Sacsaywayman. Ana Maria gave a very nice presentation in English and then translated for Prof. Salazar while he treated us to a very nice planetarium presentation about the Inca constellations and star names. After the presentation we headed outside for a look at the skies and a had peek through their telescope. We saw many things that we Northern Hemisphere dwellers never see, including the Southern Cross and the Centaur. He trained the scope on the Jewel Box, Alpha Centauri, M7, Saturn and a comet to top it all off! A very memorable night. I only wish we had more time to visit with Prof. Salazar...

Special evening experience in Cusco. The planetarium in Cusco is a special, semi-private experience, missed by most tourists to the area. On the night we went, it was just my husband and me, one other couple from the U.S., the guide and a professor. It felt like we were on a private tour with two very enthusiastic hosts. They will pick you up in Cusco and drive you up to the planetarium, nestled in the hills. Depending on the light and the clouds, your tour may vary, but for us we started outside, looking through two telescopes at different celestial objects the professor found: the rings of Saturn, distant moons, clusters of stars... then we went inside to get a tour of the planetarium from the English-speaking host, and a short star show. It was fascinating to learn about the ancient and modern local interpretations of the stars - such as that the Incans saw constellations in the black spaces of the milky way galaxies - and to learn more about the southern sky. It's not the biggest facility in the world, but the enthusiasm of the hosts and the charm with which they share their love of the stars is contagious. It was a special night!

Fascinating Experience. My girlfriend and I were really glad we did this. We did it at the end of our stay in Cusco, and we both think it would have been better to do this first - it explains the alignments of several historic buildings with the solstices, the significance of the layout of Cusco itself, and is the most historically accurate view into Cusco's past I encountered while there (some tour guides you'll come across there will be weaving their own stories). Since I had heard it all by the end of our trip and I like to challenge guides out of curiosity and to gauge credibility, I have to admit I was really impressed with the professor's knowledge. It would have been a great foundation for the rest of our visits in the Cusco area.We wished we had called earlier (we called the penultimate night) so that we could have been there on a clearer night and with a group (instead of individually since it's a lot less money), so don't make the same mistake we did there. Honestly, if it hasn't become clear already, this place was an afterthought for us, but we wish we had made it one of our targets from day one!
What a treat!. We were lucky to have a clear night. We were able to gaze at several features in the sky, so different from what you'd see here in the US.

fascinating and beautiful!. great combination of inca history and star gazing, without being too long or expensive. Highlight was seeing the rings on saturn and learning about Inca astronomy and how it influenced the city of cusco and their places of worship. A great alternative to a night out in cusco and perfect before heading to macchu picchu!!

GREAT FUN. Great introduction to the stars of the Southern Hemisphere as well as astronomy of the Incas. The guides (English and Spanish) are friendly, well informed and enthusiastic to share their knowledge. We wish we had gone out before we did the Inca trail. A great alternative night out in Cusco.

Brilliant thing to do on a cusco evening. This was a fantastic experience and very educational.
