Not only do you star gaze (we saw saturn and its rings) but you get a lesson comparing inca astrology to what know/believe today. Who would have thought cusco was built to align with the sun and that the incas could reliably predict el niño from the stars. fascinating and well worth the money. Take warm clothes as it gets very cold outside!

A must see!. The planetarium far exceeded our expectations. They were very accommodating with our schedule and were so passionate about their work. My fiancé and I are novice stargazers, but the staff at the planetarium met us at our level of understanding. Not only did we learn about the night sky of the southern hemisphere, but we learned so much about Incan history and culture. This is an amazing value and a must see if you have a free evenin in cusco!

A wonderful insight into Inca sky. This a very fascinating experience. The planetarium is modest but very well organized and wonderfully run.The stories, history, architecture of the Inca astronomy are amazing.The tour was very personal and our guide Ana Maria very knowledgable. We got to see Saturn and it's rings.Don't miss out on this experience!My advise though bring layers and hats it gets cold.

A very unique experience!. This is a one-of a kind experience in Cusco that I definitely recommend! You learn so much about the theories and constellations. And the dome with the simulated display of constellations is fascinating!

A stellar evening.. This is a fantastic way to spend an evening in Cusco. We were blessed with clear skies and so after a tour of the Planetarium inside, where clever displays show the ancient methods of stargazing, we were taken outside and treated to a quick tour of the star systems available to us that night. Then we looked through the telescope at parts of the Solar System, before returning inside for the actual Planetarium show. The Plantarium is a family run enterprise and as well as imparting to us their expert knowledge it is obvious that the people involved are there because they want to be. Their passion for the heavens is infectious. Highly recommended.

Starry Night in Cusco, Peru!. only spent 2 nights in peru. i'm glad one of them was used to experience planetarium cusco. while the explanations on the importance of astronomy to the Incas was interesting, the virtual display, night sky viewing of the southern constellations and especially the telescopic viewing of Saturn, Venus, jewel box star cluster, alpha centuri... were extrordinary. would highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys looking up at the stars even if only for a moment.

Nice. A short and pleasant activity for a reasonable price, certainly worth experiencing if you want to know more about the Incas' astronomy knowledge which influenced their art and way of building cities, temples etc., and above all of course if you want to discover the Southern hemisphere sky in the planetarium and outside with profesional material and thus be able to have a short but magic look at, among others, Saturn and its rings, Venus, the Southern Cross, or the mountains and valleys of the... Moon.

Wonderful experience ~ Highly recommended to Astronomy enthusiasts. If you love stars, you have to go there ~ pick up/drop off from hotel. Dr. Erwin and team are true enthusiasts with big hearts in promoting the rich cultural and astronomical ties within Cusco. Go check it out before all the light pollution "invades" Cusco. With the unique location of Cusco, can see 80% of the sky ! They are a private organization striving to preserve the culture ~ Excellent work Ana Maria, Roberto & Dr. Erwin ~ Please keep up the good work !

not to be missed. This one one of the hightlights of our trip. My daughter who teaches high school astronomy said that the history of Inca astronomy was wonderful. THe staff were friendly, knowledgeable. Because you are over 10,000 feet high there is so little atomsphere that the images of the plantes, Ring nebula, star clusters and other sky objects was amazing. We were part of a group but flt as if we had an individual tour. The Professor of Astronomy is a charming gentleman who answered all questions in a kind, intelligent manner. Not to be missed. If I return to Cusco I will be back with this wonderful group. Finally this is one of the few times when the price was really too low for all of the value Paul Hart

Astronomically Amazing. Planetarium Cusco was beyond a great and relaxed experience. Ana Maria was a lot of help reserving time to show us around. It included Transportation to and from the sight and wonderful descriptions of Astronomy in Peru and in general. The most interesting part was the Inca Astronomy information that they provided. Definitely a must see sight. Breath taking views of the night sky. Suitable for all ages.

A wonderful night at the Cusco Planetarium. The Cusco Planetarium is a unique and fantastic opportunity for visitors to Peru. Visits are arranged by individual appointment. They include transportation to the site and begin around 6:30 pm. The facility is located on the hillside over looking the city or Cusco, Peru. It is small and informal but the exhibits and presentations are professionally done. Information is in English and Spanish and is suitable for Adults and for children. The typical presentation covers general astronomy, the Southern night sky, and the Astronomy of the Incas. It involves a brief lecture, two presentations in an intimate but high-quality planetarium, and then live outdoor star-gazing. The staff is very knowlegeable and informative. They can answer any questions you may have and tailor the experience to your interests. Dress warmly and expect to have a good time.

one of the best things we did in Cusco. We found out about this place from a lonely planet recommendation and were fortunate that the owners could arrange a spur-of-the-moment group visit the night before we left on the Inca Trail. Though it doesn't explicitly say on the website, you can book visits most any day, so just send them an email. We had no disappointments, it was reasonably priced and lots of fun.This is a locally-inspired venture by a friendly guide and an astronomy professor who is absolutely enamored with the sky, and makes you feel that way too as you learn the constellations of the southern skies through a telescope on the outskirts of cusco. Genuine oohs and aahs galore!If you're in town for more than 2 days, I would not miss this one.

Excellent - recommended. My husband and I visited this planetarium in March 2010. We had a great time! The visit was very entertaining and educational. They picked us up in front of our hotel and drove us to the planetarium (very close to Cusco) and back again. The tour was in English. We really recommend this activity!!

Cusco Planetarium. When I was planning a trip to Peru last November with my family I tried to find an observatory but had no luck. Having never been to the southern hemisphere, I thought it would be interesting to take a look at some of the southern hemisphere's sky objects. Fortunately, I found out about the Cusco Planetarium just before we left. I contacted them and they agreed to meet us at our hotel in Cusco and take us to the planetarium. This was the night before we were heading out to Machu Picchu.The planetarum is located at the edge of town within a small ecological reserve. They picked us up at 5:30, and we arrived 10 minutes later. We went in and Ana Maria provided a 15 minute lecture (in English!) of the southern sky and its relation to Inca culture. This was very good and I recommend it to anyone prior to going to Machu Picchu. You will understand the astronomical objects and features of the site better.We then went into the planetarium. Ana Maria was joined by her father (the astronomer brains) and they pointed out the Southern Cross and other constellations, as well as Alpha Centauri (the closest star to earth after the sun), and other objects. They discussed their meaning to local cultures. We spent about a half hour there.Then we went outside just as the space station flew by, which was cool. They provided hot drinks and kept a wood stove burning to keep us warm (it gets surprisingly cold in Cusco at night because of its elevation) as we looked at several constellations and other objects with the naked eye to get oriented. Then they pulled out an 8" reflecting telescope and we looked at several features - the Jewel Box cluster (the prettiest object I've ever viewed through a telescope), Saturn with two of its moons, a variety of other open and closed clusters, and a binary star. They then drove us back to our hotel by 7:30.I highly recommend the planetarium. It is not the typical "touristy" fare. You will see a real slice of Cusco, get a concise lecture on the southern sky and what it meant to earlier cultures, and see beautiful objects that you can never see in the northern hemisphere. The price is very reasonable, too. My only regret is that I did not try and talk them into pulling out the 14" Celestron reflecting telescope I spied by one of the exhibits to take a look at some deep space objects, but maybe next time.This tour is appropriate for kids of all ages and will please non-astronomers as well as astronomers unfamiliar with the southern hemisphere sky. My boys (12 and 10), and my wife both enjoyed it as much as I did.
